PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That we are totally opposed to the introduction of the Australia Card
(2) That this national identity system will be intrusive, will not appreciably combat tax or social security fraud, is authoritarian and alien to the Australian way of life.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That we are totally opposed to the introduction of a compulsory national identification system under the control of the Federal Government.

2. That we reject the identity card proposal because it will involve massive expenditure of taxpayers funds while being ineffective in combating the problems of tax evasion, illegal immigration and abuse of the social security system.
3. That we are deeply concerned at the invasion of each Australian's privacy and the loss of their freedom that would occur if the identity card was introduced.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Se-nate should:
Reject the identity card or allow for a national refe-rendum so the Australian people can decide themselves whether they want the costly, ineffective and intrusive un-Australian identity system.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable President and Senators in Parliament assembled. We, your humble petitioners, pray that, in accordance with the wishes of a substantial number of the people of Australia, the Australia Card Bill be rejected, and we in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully requests that the Australia Card legislation be rejected because the proposed system:
(1) has been demonstrated to have no capacity to stop tax evasion, Social Security fraud, illegal immigration or to recoup the revenue lost through abuse of these systems as was claimed.
(2) will impose a large financial impact on Australian citizens, and has been demonstrated by the Parliament's own Joint Committee to be not cost effective.
(3) has been shown to have the capacity to actually aid and abet both illegal immigration and organised crime.

(5) does not contain the very necessary barriers to invasion of privacy, and loss of personal liberties.
(6) will in both the words of the Government and the HIC be enlarged to encompass far greater uses, and the compilation of much more information on the data base.

And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Taxation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
(i) the fringe benefits tax will place enormous cost increases on employers throughout Australia;
(ii) in so doing, the fringe benefits tax will raise the cost of employing labour particularly in remote locations and it will inevitably worsen the already high level of unemployment in Australia;
(iii) much of the cost of the tax will be carried by employees as employers reduce benefits; and

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned expresses concern that some scientists in Australia are intent on under-taking destructive experimentation on human embryos. This subject was examined exhaustively by the 1985-86 Senate Select Committee on Senator Harradine's Human Embryo Experimentation Bill which received 27 submissions and more than 2,000 pages of evidence. The report of the Senate Committee recommended in October 1986 that the Commonwealth Government make unlawful any destructive experiment which frustrated the development of the human embryo.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to:
Implement without delay the major recommendation of the Senate Select Committee to outlaw destructive experiments on human embryos.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of the Senate assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. The present Australian national flag is not distinctively and uniquely Australian and is confused with other national flags.
2. The people of Australia have never had an opportunity to express their views on an appropriate Australian national flag in a referendum.
3. The present Australian national flag does not properly represent Australia as a sovereign, independent nation.
4. The present Australian national flag incorrectly proclaims Australia as a colony, homeland, protectorate, dominion or government department of Great Britain.
5. The first condition in the flag competition of 1901 required that the design should show Australia's loyalty to the British Empire. The British Empire no longer exists.
6. A public opinion poll held in 1984 using the Gallup Method revealed that 52 per cent of Australians surveyed wanted a competition for a new design for the Australian flag.
7. There is no inherent link between Australia proclaiming a unique and distinctive flag and the political issue of Australia moving to a republican form of government.
8. The adoption of a truly Australian national flag would serve as a focal point for Australia's bicentennial celebrations in 1988.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
(a) Appoint a Committee of the Parliament with representatives from both Houses and all parties to invite and consider proposals for the design of a new Australian national flag, and

(b) Require that Committee to make recommendations on the form of a minimum cost referendum in which the electors will be given the opportunity to vote for a flag from a selection of at least three designs, one of which will be the present Australian national flag.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Does the Minister agree with his colleague Mr Willis, who said on Friday that the whole array of effects of the share market crash could be `very considerable' with possible impact on Australia's terms of trade, the exchange rate, interests rates, investor confidence, capital flow and consumer confidence? If so, does he agree that the Government should keep open the option of a mini-Budget before the end of the current parliamentary session?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will sensibly examine the implications of the fall in the stock market for the world economy and the Australian economy. It may well be that some of the areas outlined by Mr Willis will require examination. Mr Willis was doing no more than stating an obvious agenda of could-bes, rather than making any findings on the run as to what the implications or results of the fall may in fact prove to be for the Australian economy. That remains to be seen. We will make our assessments over the next few weeks, but we certainly will not be rushing in to form half-baked views about the implications of the market's movements. We see calls for mini-Budgets as essentially fairly mindless, calls for major policy shifts-something which is not being contemplated by the Government. The policy changes, particularly fiscal policy, that have been achieved by the Australian Government are really in advance of the rest of the world and especially the United States. The kind of knee-jerk responses that are suggested by the Opposition would serve only to inflame the sense of crisis, something which we see as being hardly conducive to the restoration of order in the stock market.

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised by the Treasurer-I think he will be saying as much in the other House-that for all of these reasons there will be no mini-Budget during the remainder of calendar year 1987. As is usual, the Government will consider the option of a statement of initial budgetary measures-a May-type statement-at the appropriate time; that is, early next year. Whether the option to proceed with a May-type statement is taken up will depend on a range of factors which will be weighed up in the balance much closer to that time.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Has his attention been drawn to an article appearing in today's Australian entitled `Insanity of 1929 repeats itself' and written by Professor J. K. Galbraith? Is it the Minister's view that the lessons Professor Galbraith draws regarding the United States economy need to be given serious consideration in setting Australian economic policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the first part of the question is that I have seen the article. I do not think that the Australian Government can learn much from it because the Government already knows the points Professor Galbraith made. The Opposition, however, could certainly benefit from studying it because, as I understand it, the Opposition still goes along with supply-side voodoo, incentivation and all that sort of thing. The Liberal Party certainly had supply-side voodoo in the policy it presented during the recent election campaign. I also note for the record that Senator Stone stopped far short of endorsing the proposition that if income tax rates were lower, there would be a very major increase in revenue because people would work harder and so on. Professor Galbraith ridicules that proposition in these words:

ANSWER.PARA: I do not believe the Reagan-Thatcher doctrine that the rich have not been working because they have too little money while the poor have not been working because they have too much money.

Apart from being counter-intuitive, all the empirical evidence of which I am aware supports Galbraith's assessment or, at the very least, does not contradict it. There is only one error of omission on Galbraith's part when he referred to the Reagan-Thatcher doctrine. It is, of course, the Reagan-Thatcher-Howard-Bjelke-Petersen and, to a very limited extent, even Stone doctrine as well, and that is not a comprehensive list. That supply-side voodoo upon which that sort of assessment is based is still the official policy of the Opposition in Australia, as I under-stand it. In regard to the causes of the recent stock market collapse, Galbraith made the point which many others have made, and that is that all of this has happened before. He said:

Once this one has worked itself out, there is no early danger of another crash. The financial memory is about 10 years. That is about the time between one episode of sophisticated stupidity and the next. So we don't have to worry for the next 10 years.
Although this is directed at the Reagan Adminisration, it ought to be studied and absorbed by the Opposition. Apart from the 10-year cycle or thereabouts to which Galbraith referred, he said:
For the disasters of this past week we must hold the Reagan administration substantially responsible.
Two great innovations carry a large share of the blame. There was first the extraordinary notion that, by large reductions in taxes, one could have large increases in income.
In other words, that is supply-side voodoo. He continued:
This produced an unparalleled deficit in the public budget and lodged a great deal of speculative money in the hands of people who put it into the market.
I commend the reading of Galbraith's article to members of the Opposition and hope that they devote a very long period to trying to think through the implications of it for their policy.

—I address my question to the Minister for Justice and Minister administering the Department of the Attorney-General. Has the Minister noted the statement last week by the Executive Director of the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC), Mr Schoer, that the Commission is monitoring stockbroking firms to ensure that they are solvent and able to cope with the volume of business arising from the gyrations on the stock market in recent days? Is the Minister also aware of Mr Schoer's recent statement to Senate Estimates Committee E that a lack of adequate funding and resources has forced the NCSC to downgrade significantly its monitoring and surveillance responsibilities, and that in some areas staff resources are down by as much as two-thirds? Is the Minister satisfied that the Commission does have the capacity to perform its responsibilities, particularly in view of the major developments in the financial markets over the past week? If not, will the Government take urgent steps to increase the resources available to the Commission in order to strengthen public confidence?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not available to me in the brief from the Attorney-General specific material which would enable me to reply to statements apparently made by Mr Schoer, the Executive Director of the National Companies and Securities Commission. But I can make a general response on the question of the investigatory resources of the Commission which might help the honourable senator in a more general sense. The resources available to the NCSC include not only the 82 staff at its office in Melbourne but also over 1,400 staff Australia-wide serving in the NCSC's delegates, namely, the Corporate Affairs Commission in each State and Territory. These resources should be used by the NCSC in carrying out its investigative work. Surveillance of the markets and corporate behaviour is a most important function and should be given the highest priority. If surveillance work is suffering because priorities are given to other functions, those other priorities and functions must be carefully examined.

ANSWER.PARA: In December 1986 the Attorney-General asked questions about the use of resources and the allocation of priorities by the NCSC within the co-operative scheme. The NCSC indicated that it believed that, in the light of the Federal nature of the scheme and because its delegates report directly to their separate governments, it was not appropriate for the NCSC to try to set their internal priorities. The NCSC further suggested that in practice the functions carried out by the NCSC and its delegates are largely separate.

The inefficiency and misallocation of resources within the present co-operative scheme demonstrated by this situation is one of the main reasons why the Commonwealth is now moving to establish a truly national system of corporate regulation. In a Commonwealth scheme all the resources in Australia available to the proposed Australian Securities Commission for corporate surveillance and investigation will be able to be effectively managed and co-ordinated to ensure the operation of fair and efficient markets in the national interest. In moving to establish a Commonwealth scheme, the Government is carefully examining current priorities and functions to ensure that scarce and valuable resources are directed away from time-consuming and unnecessary functions to enable more resources to be devoted to essential surveillance and monitoring work.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health in her responsibility for housing. Is the Minister aware of the Opposition's claims of a $468m cut in public housing funding? Can the Minister explain to the Senate how the Opposition has arrived at this figure? Is this another example of the Opposition's notoriety for supplying incorrect figures to the electorate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Porter's claims are completely unfounded. Focusing on current waiting lists for public housing does not take account of the Federal Government's impressive track record in the public housing area since coming to office. The $468m mentioned by Mr Porter is an erroneous figure. It represents the reduction in the total borrowing component of the States' Loan Council borrowing program, plus a reduction in the forward estimate for Commonwealth-State Housing Authority funding in 1987-88. Loan Council funds available for public housing at the concessional rate of 4.5 per cent actually fell by only $170m. The decision to accept cuts to the Loan Council borrowing program, and hence to low interest funds available for public housing, was made by State Premiers at the 1987 Premiers Conference. Premiers could have accepted cuts in other areas.

ANSWER.PARA: A balanced Budget for 1987-88 and the withdrawal of the Federal Government as a net borrower this year have had a positive impact on interest rates. The predominant rate on new savings bank loans is now 14.5 per cent; some permanent building societies are offering starting interest rates of less than 14 per cent to first home buyers. Dwelling commencements in 1986-87 were a disappointing 116,200, but this was still 10.7 per cent greater than the Opposition's last dismal effort in 1982-83. The Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry has forecast dwelling commencements to increase to between 126,000 and 130,000 in 1987-88, a 10 per cent increase on last year. Comparing mortgage repayments as a proportion of income now with the situation a decade ago is meaningless. It ignores the effect of second incomes on borrowing capacity, the impact of inflation on house prices, the average size of loans actually taken out and the impact of government assistance programs. I remind honourable senators that since its introduction in 1983, the first home owners scheme has assisted 246,000 households into home ownership.

—My question is to the Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health in her responsibility for housing. Is it correct that this year-the International Year of Shelter for the Homeless-Commonwealth new money for the supported accommodation assistance program will not be accepted in full by the States and therefore will not be available for assistance to homeless people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth has provided new funds each year since the supported accommodation assistance program was introduced by the Labor Government in 1984-85. A total of $76.1m was provided in 1986-87 for refuges, half-way houses, referral services, sexual assault and counselling centres and other support services assisting people in crisis throughout Australia. This represents an increase of 90 per cent on funding for this type of activity since the program was first introduced in 1984-85. The Commonwealth has already guaranteed a further $5m plus indexation funds for 1988-89 to ensure the continued growth of this important work. It is true that not all States and Territories have accepted the full Commonwealth offer of $5m new money under the supported accommodation assistance program for 1987-88. In fact, the Northern Territory has only accepted $11,000 out of the $225,000 new moneys offered. With the exception of South Australia, which has not yet formally accepted the Commonwealth's offer, all other States will accept the new money in 1987-88.

ANSWER.PARA: Under the terms of the agreement with the States any funds not taken up will be redirected to those States and Territories that have accepted the Commonwealth's offer in full. Thus the $5m new Commonwealth money for supported accommodation in 1987-88 will be fully allocated to new projects and to the enhancement of existing services. In addition to providing $5m in new money, the Commonwealth is also providing some $2.6m for indexing salaries and operating costs of existing refuges and other services. The significant increases in Federal funding in this area reflect the Labor Government's commitment to assist those in real need in the community, even in times of severe budgetary restraint.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. I remind him that on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation television program Four Corners last month he said in relation to corruption in the Queensland Police Force that it filled him with foreboding `when the stench of corruption reaches so high that the work of the National Crime Authority (NCA) may have been compromised'. The Minister must be aware that the work of the NCA is also threatened by corruption in other forces. What steps has he taken to ensure that the work of the Authority is not compromised further?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In general I can assure the chamber and, indeed, those who are listening, that the National Crime Authority's operations and the protection of its witnesses-a point particularly raised by Senator Hill in a question a couple of weeks ago-have, as far as one can judge and on advice available to me from Mr Justice Stewart, not been compromised by the events surrounding, in particular, Mr Parker in his role as liaison officer with the National Crime Authority over several years. Nevertheless, a general point needs to be addressed. To that end, only last Friday I wrote to Mr Justice Stewart bringing to his attention the fact that I am placing on the agenda of the intergovernmental committee meeting in Hobart on 27 November the question of the appointment of liaison and contact police personnel whose task it is, as the term implies, to liaise between the National Crime Authority and the State police force concerned.

ANSWER.PARA: I wrote to Mr Justice Stewart indicating the principles I would like to see adopted are that the nomination of liaison or contact officers should be acknowledged to be subject to the right of refusal by the receiving agency-in other words, that the nominee of the police force concerned is not automatically accepted by the National Crime Authority-and further that the liaison or contact officer nominated should be by reference to the individual concerned and not by reason of the office he or she might hold. Certainly, in Mr Parker's case he has succeeded to the post of Assistant Commissioner (Crime), the liaison officer in that office having been accepted some time before. As I say, I wrote to Mr Justice Stewart on Friday informing him that the matter would be on the agenda on Friday, 27 November, and seeking his views, which I expect to get shortly.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also addressed to the Minister for Justice and follows on from the previous question. I refer the Minister to the recent arrest, following investigations by the National Crime Authority (NCA), of the Assistant Commissioner (Crime) in South Australia, Mr Kevin Harvey, on a charge of conspiring to pervert the course of justice. In view of this most disturbing development, can the Minister advise whether, and to what extent, Mr Harvey would have had access, as a consequence of his senior and specialised position in the South Australian police force, to any NCA sensitive material?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some of the matters I raised in answer to Senator Newman cover matters raised in Senator Bolkus's question, but in general honourable senators are aware not only that liaison officers are appointed in a formal sense but also that in the exchange of intelligence at the working police level there is quite a bit of tick-tacking between the National Crime Authority and various State police forces. I am advised that Mr Harvey was not a nominated liaison officer to the NCA for the South Australian police force but that he had previously attended a number of National Crime Authority operational conferences as follows: three in 1984, four in 1985, two in 1986 and one in 1987. I am also advised that as far as the Authority is aware at this stage the presence of Mr Harvey at those meetings has not jeopardised any of the Authority's investigations nor put at risk any of the Authority's witnesses or informants. That is the advice I have received from the NCA as late as just before Question Time.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators will be aware from the answer I gave to Senator Newman that clearly there is a need to tighten up procedures in this liaison contact role. It is to that end that I hope that, at the ministerial level, in late November a good working relationship can be reinstituted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also ask a question of the Minister for Justice. In answering a question I asked on 9 October, I understood the Minister for Justice to indicate that he favoured the establishment of units `to bring about, within government agencies, a system of prevention, detection and investigation of fraud'. Does this imply that this system would be instead of using the services of the regular police? Would it involve recruiting officers from existing police services to operate it? Would such a scheme only further fragment an already overfragmented law enforcement service?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was trying to indicate to the Senate that when the Australian Federal Police (AFP), being the pre-eminent law enforcement agency of the Commonwealth, is, under its charter given by this Government in 1983, undertaking its whole orientation to major matters of importance involving breaches of the criminal law, whether they be organised crime, drug trafficking or major fraud against the Commonwealth, it is not thought to be a sensible use of those valuable police resources to have Australian Federal Police engaged in some of the preventive and minor matters which can inundate them otherwise.

ANSWER.PARA: To repeat the example I have given many times in this chamber, we found that the Federal Police were dealing with tens of thousands of cases of social security cheque theft from letterboxes and with fraud when those who had received the cheques claimed that they had not and got emergency relief through social security or social welfare agencies. The person years that were used up by the Australian Federal Police in pursuit of those matters were a terrible waste of its resources. It is far better that the more highly trained and more goal oriented task forces that we now have within the Federal Police be given the task of pursuing major fraud against the Commonwealth.

For that reason, the Commonwealth Government has decided that within each agency upstream of the Australian Federal Police-the prosecution agencies and the courts-much more attention should be paid to preventive measures and to carrying out investigations, as of course many agencies already do. Within the Department of Social Security and the Australian Taxation Office, for example, a lot of the investigations are undertaken by persons well qualified within those agencies. It is hoped that that particular model will be adopted by other agencies to relieve pressure on the Federal Police.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Does the Minister believe that the highly specialised investigation of these matters can be carried out by people without a police background? Is he not concerned that middle ranking to senior officers will leave to go to a much better existence in divisions?

—The question of the attraction to members of the Australian Federal Police of jobs within other government agencies is one with which I am always concerned. I must admit that there have been occasions when there has been that loss and drift to other agencies, and to the private sector for that matter, because of the skills imparted to the Australian Federal Police officers in their training and experience. But, of course, there are other factors at work, including the superannuation scheme, which my colleague the Minister for Finance and I are working on at the moment in order to make it more attractive for those from the very age groups and rankings that Senator Archer spoke of to remain within the AFP and to give us the benefit of their experience up to a reasonable retirement age. I believe that the fraud control committee established by the Government will call on the Australian Federal Police to ensure that those undertaking these tasks within agencies do acquire from members of the Australian Federal Police some of the skills that are required. I hope there will be co-operation in that transfer of skills.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to reports that the Australian Taxation Office alleges that a former Queensland Police Licensing Branch officer, Mr Jack Herbert, now believed to be overseas, owes unpaid taxes amounting to more than $800,000? Can the Minister say whether this is the same Mr Herbert who is believed to have enormous real estate holdings in Queensland and who is required to give evidence before the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct in that State? What measures have been taken by the Federal authorities to locate Mr Herbert and have him returned to Australia? What has been the level of co-operation from the Queensland Government in this regard?

—I have not had drawn to my attention in a formal way any allegation by the Australian Taxation Office that a former Queensland Police Licensing Branch officer, Mr Jack Herbert, now believed to be overseas, owes unpaid taxes amounting to more than $800,000. But I believe that any reference to that Mr Jack Herbert must be to the same Mr Jack Herbert who does hold real estate holdings in Queensland of a significant nature. As I have indicated to the chamber before, the fact is that, if Mr Herbert is overseas, extradition proceedings can be undertaken only by the Federal Government and that can be done only in relation to pending court proceedings and not in relation to a commission of inquiry such as is being undertaken by Mr Fitzgerald. The fact is that the Queensland Government has not approached the Federal Government at all in relation to the return to Australia of Mr Herbert, but should it do so, of course, the Federal Government will undertake in a most co-operative way whatever measures are required-within the limits that I have noted, namely, that it must be in relation to his being sought in relation to pending court proceedings.

—Can the Minister for Local Government inform the Senate what the average loss of income will be for local government authorities caused by the substitution of annual payments by quarterly payments of Commonwealth financial assistance to local government? What steps is the Minister taking to ascertain the financial problems that this may cause local authorities?

—I thank Senator Knowles for her question. I am not able to give her a precise figure as to the annual loss to local government of quarterly payments. However, I am able to say that that decision was taken in the context of the May economic statement. It is very important that all areas of government and, indeed, the community generally exercise restraint, and the decision in relation to quarterly payments was made by the Government to ensure that local government was exercising the restraint that was being asked of the rest of the community. In talking to local authorities all over Australia, I am well aware that there was a degree of disappointment amongst many local authorities that they could no longer invest their full year's payments. However, only on Friday when I was speaking to some 13 local authorities in south-east Queensland I received an assurance from them that they were prepared to do their bit in terms of exercising this restraint. I am happy to take on notice the early part of Senator Knowles's question in terms of the actual financial loss, as she puts it, and think it is important that we know this in terms of recognising the contribution of local government.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Is the Minister aware of some anxiety among people who are buying their homes through the defence service homes scheme about the sale of their mortgages? There are fears that the sympathetic handling of problems that they have received in the past may cease with that sale. Are these fears justified?

—In answer to the first part of Senator Zakharov's question, yes, I am aware that some people have queried whether their low interest rates would be affected by the sale of the present portfolio of defence service home mortgages. However, I am pleased to say that the terms of any sale will involve preserving the concessional interest rate which applies to existing loans. As to the second part of the honourable senator's question, I would say that the ancillary aspects of the scheme are presently being examined as part of the overall consultative process with the Returned Services League of Australia (RSL) and other bodies. The Government has received a submission from the RSL and has formed a group of officials to be headed by a business person and to include a representative from each of the RSL and the departments of Veterans' Affairs, Defence, Finance, and Prime Minister and Cabinet. The aim of the group is to look constructively at the Government's proposals, along with the variations which the RSL has developed, with a view to presenting an urgent report to Government. It is envisaged that the report will be available in time for it to be considered by Government, with a view to making an announcement of a final decision before the end of this year.
—Does the Minister for Finance agree that, to be effective, a wealth tax would have to include the family home?

—That question is based on a number of suppositions, speculations, rumours and so on, including rumours that have been in the Press about what I am alleged to have said at some meeting or other, and, on that basis, I have no comment to make.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Home Affairs. The last publication of the Commonwealth electoral roll in book form took place in 1984, prior to the Federal election before last. When does the Government intend to publish the current electoral roll, and in what form? What is the Government's policy towards the availability of the electoral roll?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the beginning of this year it was the intention of the Australian Electoral Commission to print a new set of rolls, following the completion of the national habitation review that was under way at that stage. According to this plan, the rolls would have been produced some time before an expected Federal election, some time in late 1987 or early 1988. The unexpected holding of an election on 11 July frustrated this plan. The rolls could have been printed at that stage, but at a cost of about $800,000, and as there were going to be about 55,000 transactions at the time, the long term use of those printed rolls would have been very marginal, to say the least. So in that election we used certified lists, and these are available to anyone who is interested in obtaining them, via the Freedom of Information Act.

ANSWER.PARA: Recommendation 17 of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform, which reported to this Parliament about a year ago, suggests that rolls should be printed at least every two years into the life of a government, and that is when we would anticipate the next hard copy coming into print and being available. In the meantime, the Government is intent that, once it completes a full time habitation review, it will be able to make the electoral roll available to a variety of people via microfiche, and certainly to members of parliament and to other interested people. We are also looking at whether we can make the electoral roll available in some sort of computer form for members of parliament, and that is being examined at the moment.

We get plenty of letters from people from all over the place, asking why we have not printed an electoral roll and saying how outrageous it is that we have not. Most of those people want to use the roll for chasing people who are dodging maintenance or for some other purpose. The purpose of the electoral roll is simply one thing: to have a person's name crossed off every two years and three months, whenever we hold a Federal election. That is the purpose it serves. It has to be a public document so that everyone can examine it and make sure that it is on the up and up. As such, it has been used over the years by a variety of researchers, real estate agents and everyone else. If any of those people still want to use the roll, they can fork out enough money and get it under freedom of information.

However, the one other group that certainly uses the roll, and uses it very effectively, is members of parliament. I am looking at making special arrangements for them, as we will not have a hard copy roll for a couple of years, either via microfiche or floppy discs that they can stick in the brand new and very expensive computers that they are getting.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEFENCE HOUSING IN THE NORTHERN TERRITORY

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Is it a fact that the houses built at Tindal in the Northern Territory for the defence forces are of designs suitable for the cold Adelaide suburban climate? Is it true that the design requires air-conditioning to make the houses habitable, as they are devoid of any self-cooling properties? Is it true that air-conditioning electricity charges will average $1,000 per quarter, which is quite beyond the means of a service family to pay?

—I do not have any of the finer details to hand at the moment to the question raised by Senator MacGibbon. I will contact the Minister for Defence and get Senator MacGibbon an answer to that question later this week.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Does the Minister have any information in relation to the government process surrounding the establishment of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System? What does the information say about the pace of the implementation of the declaration about the Australian financial system, including the exchange rate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, fortuitously I do have some information about the development of policy mentioned in the Campbell report, which was published in last Saturday's Australian newspaper in the review of a book which is to be launched next week by the President elect of the Liberal Party, just to rub a bit more salt in, and which is in fact the authorised biography of the former Liberal Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser. In that book Mr Fraser, to put it mildly, dumps on Mr Howard. He also dumps on a former Governor-General, but he is probably not terribly relevant to anything these days, except probably the demand for grapes. I read from a quotation of the authorised biography of the former Liberal Prime Minister. It deals with the development of policy which ultimately led to the Campbell Committee of Inquiry. It says:

ANSWER.PARA: For months Howard produced nothing. In early May the monetary policy committee yet again asked him to bring forward a submission on proposed terms of reference.
Fraser was by now frustrated and annoyed by the slow progress Howard was making, and across the top of his . . . Cabinet minute of early February-
that is, in 1978, I think-
he had scrawled `decision designed to get action. Sick of waiting'.
Yet another two months had to go by until, in mid-July 1978, the monetary policy committee finally received the possible terms of reference Fraser had expected to receive five months earlier.
A further reference states:
In 1977 Professor Rose-
who was then an economic adviser to the Prime Minister, Mr Fraser-
and the economic adviser in the Treasurer's office, Professor John Hewson-
who was once very colourfully described as a meretricious player flitting across the stage-a colourful phrase employed by Senator Stone, as he now is-
wrote a joint note to Mr Fraser and then Mr Lynch recommending a more flexible system-
that is, on the exchange rate-

The prime minister took both the note and its authors to the Cabinet's monetary policy committee. The committee asked them to ``put their idea into action-but not to tell the Treasury who would only try to sabotage it''.

I think it is fair enough in that context to read for `not to tell the Treasury', not to tell the then Treasury Secretary or he will try to sabotage it. Finally-I think this bit is too good not to quote:

But the biography is harsh in its summary of Mr Howard: ``Even on issues where Fraser and Howard were in agreement . . . Howard, as the minister concerned, seemed not to have the necessary political clout and leadership simply to force things through more quickly in the face of opposition from Treasury.''

Again, I think we are entitled to read for `Treasury' the then Treasury Secretary. The article is headed, `Fraser guns for Howard over economic deregulation ``myth'' '. One of the more unedifying spectacles in recent Australian politics has been the way that the heavies of the Tory side of politics, whether they were in the bureaucracy or the Parliament, have insisted on dumping on each other-and in particular the reciprocal dumping between Mr Howard, Mr Fraser and Senator Stone.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to an answer given earlier in Question Time when he dismissed out of hand any suggestions for an early mini-Budget. I refer the Minister to an article by Max Walsh in today's Sydney Morning Herald entitled `What we need to know to avoid financial crisis'. Mr Walsh commented that the Cabinet, when it sits down today, must `realise that the assumptions on which the September Budget was made-especially those applying to business investment and export income-are now inoperable'. I ask the Minister whether he agrees with the conclusions of the article that `tough and rapid fiscal action' is needed in order to keep interest rates as low as possible and that a `May mini-Budget would be tragically late'.

—When I said earlier that the calls for a mini-Budget were being made mindlessly, I must confess I had in mind more Mr Sinclair than Mr Walsh, whose article at least has the merit of some beginnings of understanding of the rudimentary laws of economics, which is a little more than can be said for the key spokesmen on the Tory side. But, having made that particular peace, I repeat that the Government simply does not see any need for a mini-Budget at this stage. We have no plans for a mini-Budget. The direct impact of the stock market decline on the 1987-88 Budget is expected to be small. The Budget outlook is monitored closely and continuously by the Government. We remain committed to responsible fiscal and economic management. As I said earlier, we will continue to monitor the effects of the fall in share prices on the general economic outlook and we will take appropriate policy action if it is required. No more than that can reasonably be asked of the Government.

—Is the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate aware that the recommendations of the Constitutional Commission contain the provision that the government of the day may call a joint sitting of both Houses without a prior double dissolution to pass any legislation the Senate has failed to pass in the preceding six months? Is the Minister aware of growing community concern that such a provision would effectively spell the end of the Australian bicameral system, reducing the Senate to the status of a talk shop without any effective relevance to the legislative process? In view of this community concern, can the Minister assure the Senate that the Government will not include this particular provision in any future referendum on constitutional changes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will be considering the Commission's recommendations once it reports fully and finally some time before 30 June next year on the full area of its terms of reference. At this stage the Commission has released only a few recommendations. It is due shortly to begin considering the reports of its advisory committees, which cover a full range of possible constitutional provisions, and will do that in the light of public responses to its initial recommendations or reports. It is important not to confuse, as some have, the views of the Commission with the views of the Government or, for that matter, with the views of the Commission's advisory committees.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the Commission's recommendation on four-year terms, the Government is committed to a referendum on that subject matter but has not yet decided on the details of its proposal. I think all Australians, including all political parties, should not react prematurely or in any half-baked way to the Commission's deliberations. What we should all be doing is working in a commonly constructive, sensible and rational way--

TALK.START.PARA: —With that crowd! You must be joking.

—Which is beyond the resources, capacity and inclination of a number of honourable senators, not least the former Secretary to the Treasury who is fulminating away on the front bench. All of us should behave in a mature, responsible and constructive way, identify the problems and not go on adding to them.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the Minister tell the Senate whether he believes the recommendation to call a joint sitting without a prior double dissolution would be mature consideration of that topic?

—The Government is willing to give mature consideration to that and any other recommendation that might be made. Whether we will accept it and what the strengths of the arguments are perceived to be pro and con are matters which the Government will make up its mind about in due course. It is not something to which the Government has addressed its attention.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade: What are the implications of Australia's recent ratification of three international nuclear conventions with the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Late last month Mr Hayden deposited instruments of ratification for the Convention on Early Notification of a Nuclear Accident, the Convention on Assistance in the case of a Nuclear Accident or Radiological Emergency and the Convention on the Physical Protection of Nuclear Material. Under the notification convention a state is obliged to notify other states which might be adversely affected, as well as the International Atomic Energy Agency-the IAEA-of a nuclear accident involving its military and civil facilities and activities, except nuclear weapons. All five nuclear weapon states have indicated that they will also notify, within the framework of the convention, any nuclear weapon accident which has, or might have, significant radiological effects in another state.

ANSWER.PARA: The convention on assistance provides a framework for the provision of prompt assistance by states and the IAEA to a state which requests assistance following a nuclear accident or radiological emergency. Finally, the physical protection convention lays down standards for the physical protection of nuclear material during international transport and while in domestic use, storage and transit. It also provides for international co-operation in recovering any nuclear material which may be stolen and in dealing with offences involving such material. Australia's ratification of these three conventions provides further evidence of the Government's commitment to stringent safety standards for the nuclear industry, to strict controls on nuclear materials, particularly Australian uranium, and to the strengthening of the non-proliferation regime.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations to the very belated reply I received last week from the Minister for Industrial Relations on the subject of severance pay in the building industry. In particular, I draw to his attention the Minister's indication that the Government would not endorse the severance pay scheme unless the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission was satisfied that it did not breach the wages principles. The Minister also indicated that unless the scheme was modified to fit within the wage principles, the Commonwealth would not agree to its payment on government projects. I note the Minister's acknowledgment that the existing scheme does not adhere to the national wage case principles, and ask him to agree that as a matter of simple logic it must therefore be in breach of the Government's code of conduct. If he agrees with this simple proposition, I ask him whether the Government intends to take action to exclude those who have breached the code of conduct from future government works; and, if not, why not.

—I did glance at the answer supplied to Senator Chaney last Friday, I think. That is the day that I looked at it. But it was just a glance and it was also about three days ago and a few things have happened since. I must confess that I do not recall very clearly what was in that answer, though I accept Senator Chaney's interpretation of it. I think the real question I was asked was whether I agreed, or Mr Willis agreed, that the arrangement does not adhere to the wages policy and therefore the code of conduct. Quite frankly, I do not know whether it does, or whether Mr Willis agrees. I will ask him, as I will ask him what action he proposes to take if it is in his judgment a breach of the code of conduct for builders under government contracts.

—My question is to the Minister for Justice. Has the Minister seen media reports concerning the recent conviction of Abe Saffron on charges of conspiring to defraud the Commonwealth? Can the Minister expand upon those reports in any way? Is it true that Mr Saffron is also facing proceedings on other charges as a result of National Crime Authority investigations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have seen the reports concerning Mr Abe Saffron's recent conviction on a charge of conspiring to defraud the Federal Government of income tax. This followed investigations by the National Crime Authority under a reference issued to it by the Commonwealth Government. In passing, one of the Opposition's charges was that the intergovernmental committee arrangements whereby the National Crime Authority can exercise its extraordinary powers only on a reference from the intergovernmental committee were such that the National Crime Authority would be crippled in its investigations by governments not co-operating. That has not proved to be the case. Indeed, this is an instance where charges and a successful prosecution have resulted from detailed National Crime Authority investigations. There is little I can add to the media reports of Mr Saffron's conviction, except that the offence occurred between 1969 and 1981, and carries a maximum penalty of three years. It should be noted that the media reports have also raised the possibility of an appeal against the conviction. The trial judge has already been requested to reserve questions of law under the New South Wales Judiciary Act.

ANSWER.PARA: Finally, I can confirm that as a result of National Crime Authority investigations Mr Saffron and former New South Wales Deputy Police Commissioner William Allen were charged on 11 and 12 March with conspiracy to obstruct the course of justice and to bribe a police officer, and, in the case of Allen, with substantive bribery charges. I am not, of course, in a position to provide any further details on this matter, it being sub judice. I would like, though, to draw attention to the fact that these charges have resulted from detailed Crime Authority investigations that reflect the high level of co-operation between the Commonwealth and State governments and their respective law enforcement agencies. The Authority can undertake such investigations only when ordinary police methods at the State level have failed, and this is an instance where taking on that particular task has fully justified the Prime Minister's undertaking at the election to repeal the sunset clause. That will be undertaken by the Government as soon as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Thursday, 22 October, Senator Knowles asked me a question about the increasing level of delays in the processing of immigration applications, and in particular a business migration application from Berne in Switzerland. I undertook to obtain an answer for her. I am advised that the time of 14 months referred to in the honourable senator's question is the maximum time that it took to process a particular business migration application in Berne. This should not be regarded as indicative of the average processing time which, I am advised, is about 4.8 months, based on a sampling period of July 1986 to April 1987. However, I would like to advise Senator Knowles that the Minister, Mr Mick Young, is concerned at the delays which have occurred in the processing of individual cases in the past and, in addition to the issues being addressed generally in the current review of Australia's immigration policy, the Minister has also appointed a consultant to his staff specifically to review these processes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to provide some material in answer to a question asked by Senator Reid on 22 October 1987. Having raised some general matters of concern, Senator Reid specifically asked what police protection is provided in the Belconnen area of the Australian Capital Territory and how many police have been on duty in each shift in the area of the Belconnen police station in the last three weeks. The answer is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Obviously there is never sufficient police to fulfil every individual community expectation. The ideal situation would be to have police patrolling every street in Canberra, but that would be extremely manpower intensive, and costly. Within the ACT there is a minimum shift coverage of at least 21 police units which have an average response time of less than 8 minutes to an incident. That response is as good as, if not better than that existing elsewhere in Australia.

In specifically examining the staffing and patrolling capacity at Belconnen Police Station, it should be noted that the patrols during the last three weeks have averaged 4.47 patrols on morning shift, 4 patrols on afternoon shift, and 4.14 patrols on night shift. In the last six months, police have attended to 19 responses in the Kippax area. Some of these incidences related to alarms and lost children, others for matters involving reports of crime.

Police from Belconnen Police Station have addressed store managers and staff from Kippax Fair on security and related problems. The Manager of Kippax Fair, Mr Plows, has recently telephoned the Assistant Commissioner. Mr McConaghy, personally, to thank him for the service provided by Belconnen Police.

It is acknowledged that patrols may be tied up for extended times due to the increase in criminal activity within the ACT. However, the level of police patrols is adequate given the geographical layout of the city, and the number of related police activities within the various areas. It should be pointed out that, in addition to general duties patrols, traffic, Criminal Investigation Branch, process service and many of the supporting police units are on hand to provide backup arrangements if required.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 26 October, from Senator Stone:

INTERJECT.PARA: Dear Mr President,
Pursuant to Standing order 64, I give notice that today I propose to move-
That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
That the Senate
(1) Express its concern:
(i) that Australia's gross foreign debt, at around 40 per cent of Gross Domestic Product (GDP) is now among the highest in the world, and compares with a figure of 13 per cent in the case of the USA;

(ii) that Australia's current account deficit in the balance of payments, which is the source of this growing debt, was forecast in the budget papers at $11.5 billion, or four per cent of the GDP in 1987-88 (compared with a figure of 3.3 per cent in the case of the USA); and

(iii) that our level of business fixed investment, even prior to recent events in the stock market and financial markets generally, was forecast in the Budget papers to increase by only four per cent in real terms (after allowance of transfers of major government assets to the private sector), or little more than in line with the forecast growth in GDP;

(2) note that the state of these fundamental indicators of economic ill-health renders the Australian economy excessively vulnerable to any adverse change in world economic conditions, particularly insofar as any such change may have adverse consequences for the prices of our major export commodities;

(3) note the serious risks for Australia which are involved in the foregoing and calls upon the Government to undertake urgently measures to speed up the pace of the economic adjustment which, as conceded in the Budget papers, has to be made; and in particular; and

(4) call upon the Government, as an urgent first step in that speeding-up of the adjustment process, to introduce a mini-Budget directed at significantly cutting Government expenditure and reducing the total Public Sector Borrowing Requirement (PSBR) before the Parliament rises in December.
Yours sincerely,
JOHN STONE
Senator for the State of Queensland
Is the proposal supported?
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
That the Senate
(1) Express its concern:
(i) that Australia's gross foreign debt, at around 40 per cent of Gross Domestic Product (GDP) is now among the highest in the world, and compares with a figure of 13 per cent in the case of the USA;

(ii) that Australia's current account deficit in the balance of payments, which is the source of this growing debt, was forecast in the Budget papers at $11.5 billion, or four per cent of the GDP in 1987-88 (compared with a figure of 3.3 per cent in the case of the USA); and

(iii) that our level of business fixed investment, even prior to recent events in the stock market and financial markets generally was forecast in the Budget papers to increase by only four per cent in real terms (after allowance of transfers of major government assets to the private sector), or little more than in line with the forecast growth in GDP;

(2) note that the state of these fundamental indicators of economic ill-health renders the Australian economy excessively vulnerable to any adverse charge in world economic conditions, particularly insofar as any such change may have adverse consequences for the prices of our major export commodities;

(3) note the serious risks for Australia which are involved in the foregoing and calls upon the Government to undertake urgently measures to speed up the pace of the economic adjustment which, as conceded in the Budget papers, has to be made; and in particular; and

(4) call upon the Government, as an urgent first step in that speeding-up of the adjustment process, to introduce a mini-Budget directed at significantly cutting Government expenditure and reducing the total Public Sector Borrowing Requirement (PSBR) before the Parliament rises in December.

Last week we had, I suppose, one of the most momentous weeks in the economic history of Australia-at any rate within the living memory of most of us. We have had events-not merely, of course, in Australia-triggered initially by what might almost be called a great crash in Wall Street on Monday night, our time, in London and to a lesser degree in Tokyo, but not significantly in Hong Kong for the sole and simple reason that the authorities in that stock exchange chose to close it and suspend trading for all of last week. I understand that the Hong Kong market has opened today and has fallen by some 30 per cent.

The reason that the Opposition brought forward this motion of urgency today is our feeling, in light of responses given by Ministers-not only on the other side of this chamber but also in the other chamber-during the course of the past week and in various Press and other media exchanges, that to date the Government has shown very little or almost no sign of appreciating the full gravity of what has been occurring. Senator Walsh, in one of his earliest responses to a question in this chamber last week, said, `these things happen from time to time'. I say to the Minister that a fall of over 20 per cent in the stock market is not something which can be lightly put aside with the almost flippant comment that these things happen from time to time. Incidentally, I say with the utmost good will to the Minister and his colleagues who, I trust, will be responding in the course of this debate on the urgency motion, that I hope we will not receive from that side of the chamber the tired, irrelevant and unworthy remarks we hear far too often in this place relating to events which may or may not have happened five, eight or 10 years ago or some other time. Despite the mirth just expressed by Senator Walsh, this is no laughing matter. I hope we get from Ministers today some serious indication not only of the Government's attitude towards the events of the past week but also their attitude to what they, who occupy the treasury bench in this Parliament, propose to do to address the results of those events.

Having made those points, I say straightaway that I personally do not regard the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, as the culprit in the events that have led up to the present situation in Australia. I do not regard him as the culprit at all. Indeed, some five weeks before the recent Budget was brought down, Senator Walsh, in a very competent and workmanlike speech on 7 August, made a number of what I think can fairly be described as extremely sapient remarks. At that time Senator Walsh pointed out that, given the nature and severity of Australia's economic problems, we had only three economic policy choices. I shall list them in the order in which the Minister publicly listed them.

According to Senator Walsh, the first choice was what he called the draconian choice, described as the process of stabilising the foreign debt by imposing on ourselves a catastrophic depression of indefinite duration and frightening social consequences. The second choice listed by Senator Walsh was what he called the irresponsible choice, which was to ignore the problem until, as he put it in perhaps slightly colourful language-but the Minister is given to colourful language-the International Monetary Fund imposed a solution on us. The third choice was what he called the sensible choice, that is, to stabilise and in time reverse the growth of foreign debt as a proportion of gross domestic product by a combination of consumption restraint, economic restructuring and productivity growth.

Clearly, what Senator Walsh was doing at that time, five weeks before the Budget was brought down, was arguing publicly with his colleagues that they had to make the last of those choices-what he called the sensible choice. I suspect that I might differ a little from the honourable senator in what I would regard as the appropriate pace of adjustment, but one thing is quite certain: we clearly both differ from the view taken by his Cabinet colleagues at the time the Budget was brought down.

After the Budget was brought down, Senator Walsh made some further remarks on Sunday, 20 September, to a convention of people who, strangely enough, describe themselves as `Labor lawyers'-a contradiction in terms. Senator Walsh referred again to some remarks he had made during the biennial conference of the Australian Labor Party in Hobart at which he had commented in similar terms upon the lack of direction, or lack of seriousness, if you like, of the measures the Government, of which he is a constituent part, had employed to address Australia's growing economic and, in particular, international debt problems.

I say again that Senator Walsh is not the culprit. The culprits are the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating). The Treasurer is the culprit because of his personal ambition to move as soon as possible to the Lodge and perhaps, I note in passing, also because of his concerns that any more responsible Budget brought down could have had some adverse consequences for his colleagues in the New South Wales Labor Government who are, as everybody knows, facing an election in the not too distant future. The Prime Minister's most recent contribution to these matters, apart from his contribution to the Cabinet processes leading to a totally unsatisfactory Budget, was, I think, from Tipperary where he said that he thought Australia's economic position was fundamentally sound. I recall that the last time a Prime Minister of this country used those terms was in 1972 when Mr McMahon, now Sir William McMahon, was trying to tell everybody that Australia's economy was basically sound. He was laughed out of office and, if I may say so in passing, quite rightly so.

TALK.START.PARA: —You've said that before.

—Indeed. In the face of what I hope Senator Walsh will agree are these undeniably grave developments, we have from this Government the following: last week Senator Walsh, in response to Senator Chaney's suggestion that perhaps a postponement of the wage case might be appropriate, said that the suggestion was patently stupid. The next day the Government announced to the Senate that the wage case would be postponed for at least a week. It may be further postponed before we are through.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Walsh, in response to a question from me last week, also said-and I think he repeated it in response to other questions-that only to the extent that the events both overseas and in Australia led to two developments, firstly, a fall in the prices for our major export commodities and, secondly, a withdrawal of foreign capital from Australia, could the events be said to have consequences for the real economy. The Minister went on to say that, to that time, there had been no evidence of either. In the first case he said that only 24 hours after the events had occurred, and in the second case it was perhaps 72 hours after they had occurred. He said that by that time no evidence had accrued that either of those things was beginning to happen. That is like Senator Walsh standing in the middle of the road, with a truck coming straight at him at full speed down the road, and saying, `Only to the extent that it actually hits me need I be concerned about it. There is no evidence yet that it has done so and, until it does, I need not be concerned'. That appears to be the line of logic, if I may so describe it, that the Minister for Finance brought to his responses to honourable senators from this side of the chamber last week.

Another point that should perhaps be noted in passing is the Minister's suggestion that these days-compared with, say, earlier events in 1929; I think that was the example he mentioned-governments are much more prepared to intervene. That may be of some comfort to Senator Walsh but it is of no comfort whatsoever to me. It is because of the very fact that we have had governments intervening all over the place that we are in the mess that we are in. I regard the suggestion that the preparedness of governments to intervene should be regarded as comforting as a rather chilling indication of the degree of continuing unreality from the other side of the chamber.

The fact is that today we in Australia-and not merely we in Australia-are confronted with three basic problems. The first is that the United States economy-and indeed the world economy-is in a mess. Secondly, insofar as our own more parochial concerns are involved, the Australian economy is in an even greater mess. Thirdly, and again insofar as we are concerned, the adjustment process of which we have heard so much in recent days-the process whereby this Government has purported to take action to bring our economic affairs into better balance, to address the problem of our growing international debt, our growing burden of debt service-has been and remains simply far too complacent. Indeed, it was too complacent even before the events of the past week.

Let us take very quickly the state of the United States economy because we continue to hear-I think we shall hear it even more frequently in the days ahead-the refrain from the Government side of the chamber that it is all the fault of the United States. I think Mr Keating is even quoted today as having said something along those lines-that the United States should have taken some action to deal with its problems. I am in entire agreement with the Treasurer and, I am sure, the Minister for Finance on that subject. However, the point is that the question of whether the United States does or does not take action to deal with these problems is not within the control of the Australian Government. Until it is, which I think it unlikely to be in my lifetime, the Australian Government's responsibility is to deal with the problems of Australia within whatever is the international economic framework and regardless of what actions or inactions the United States Government, the Government of the Federal Republic of Germany or the Government of the United Kingdom do or do not take. It is that failure to face up to the realities of this uncertain and increasingly dangerous economic world that underlies the failure of the Government and renders it so urgent that the Senate should today agree with this urgency motion to express its concern about all these matters, and in particular to urge the Government to bring down a mini-Budget before the Parliament rises before Christmas.

Since the meeting in Paris in February this year of the seven major countries, the so-called G7, we have had an agreement to hold the international exchange rate structure roughly stable within some agreed band. The central banks have been working extremely hard to do that. But that has involved the central banks buying United States dollars at a tremendous rate. What has happened in the course of the past eight months since the Louvre Agreement was undertaken is that virtually the whole of the enormous United States balance of payments deficit has been financed by central banks. It has not been financed by private capital inflow in net terms. There has been private capital inflow but it has done nothing more than offset the private capital outflow. In net terms almost the whole of that enormous United States balance of payments deficit during that time has been financed by central banks. Of course, the process whereby they have done that is by selling their own currencies into their own domestic economies and buying United States dollars. This has pumped up their own money supplies, and what we have seen in the past week or two leading up to the sharp exchanges between Secretary Baker of the United States and Mr Poehl of the German Bundesbank is a process whereby countries like the Federal Republic of Germany and Japan have said, `Enough'.

It is now strongly urged-and I entirely agree with the urgings-that the United States should now move, through the Congress, to begin to address its own budgetary problem. I agree with that entirely, but let us be clear about what the economic consequence would be, in the short term at least, if it did so. Of course, the economic consequence of that would be to restrain the growth of activity in the United States economy. That is what we are asking for; that is what the Minister is asking for and that is what the Treasurer is asking for. Let us be quite clear about the fact that that is what we are asking for. So far as the Australian economy is concerned, during the course of the past week we have had a number of most serious developments in the financial markets, and I believe that a great many more have yet to emerge. We have had huge calls being made in the futures market, in the Sydney Futures Exchange market. One small firm there, Australian Corporate Finance, is already in the hands of the receivers. There have been many tragic individual wipeouts, particularly the so-called mums and dads who were enticed back into that market on Wednesday and Thursday by confidence creating, or so-called confidence inducing, calls from Ministers and, indeed, I have to say, from some major entrepreneurs also, who, no doubt with the best of intentions, have nevertheless enticed people back into those markets, as a consequence of which those people have been wiped out.

These are the tragic things that occur when markets are in the state that they are in, and when they are receiving no assurances of corrective action from the Government to which they owe their responsibility, in this case, the Australian Government. The Australian Government is simply sitting on its hands and saying that it will not do anything, that it sees no need, that nothing has changed and that the only thing that has happened is that the financial markets are falling apart. In the view of Senator Walsh there appears to be no relationship between the financial markets and the real economy. I have to assure him that there is a relationship and, unless the Government begins to take that relationship more seriously than it has so far shown any sign of doing, it will rue the consequences of not having done so.

A similar fallout, of course, has occurred overseas. There is this enormous destruction of wealth-which people thought they had only 10 days ago-in the United States and Britain, to a lesser degree in Japan, today in Hong Kong and, of course, not least, in our own country. Does the Minister not understand that when individuals are faced with that huge loss of wealth, not only in their own holdings but in the pension funds upon which, in turn, many of them will depend, it will have some effect on their behaviour in relation to their consumption patterns? Does he not understand that, as a result, savings are likely to rise, and that there will be-since he appears to find Keynes so attractive-some depressive effects on the level of activity? Does the Minister not understand that, as a consequence of that and similar factors working in those markets, the fears of inflation which have been so prevalent in the commodities market, in particular in recent months, will evaporate and that those commodity markets will be likely to feel the effects of that? Does the Minister not understand that once that inflationary stimulus, if one can call it that, has been removed from those commodity markets the Australian dollar, which is seen as the currency of a commodity country-and we are a commodity currency country-is likely to be affected by that outcome?

I put it to the Minister that Australia has become excessively vulnerable, through the large rise in debt which has occurred, to any adverse change in world economic conditions. We are now running the most serious of risks and, as the motion indicates, there is a need to undertake urgently measures to speed up the pace of the economic adjustment which we all agree is necessary. I urge Government members not to respond to this urgency motion with the kind of irrelevancies, flippancies, and unworthy remarks which we have come so much to expect from them but that they seriously address the issues involved, and to do so before this Parliament rises.
