TALK.START.PARA: —I will make some comments later about the details of Senator Stone's urgency motion, which I think is the most verbose in history, but at the beginning I want to make this general observation. In a sense I welcome it, because nowhere in this most verbose urgency motion in history is there reference to the alleged need to reduce taxation. I welcome this motion as an indication of a belated embrace of fiscal responsibility by the Opposition, a very belated embrace. I am flattered that Senator Stone has obviously studied very carefully the speech that I gave on 7 August, and even quoted quite extensively from it today. But there is one section he did not quote, which is relevant to the point I have just made, when I said:

SPEECH.PARA: In the run up to the election the Ratbag Right, (i.e., the NFF, ASBA-
that is, the National Farmers Federation and the Australian Small Business Association-

the Queensland National Party and a gaggle of feeble-minded journalists) peddled the nostrum that lower taxation was a function of economic law, that average disposable income could actually be increased, and our economic problems overcome, by bringing back the boozy tax deductible lunch, the tax deductible Mercedes, paying pensions to millionaires and exempting from taxation the speculative gains of compradors and other parasites.

For those who are not familiar with the term `comprador', which includes some people who have written about it, I explain that it is a Portuguese word, the rough translation of which in contemporary times means people who skim off the cream, probably because of some indulgence granted to them by the government, without putting any real effort into it. Hence the reference to compradors and other parasites, a comprador being a particular type of parasite. Having made that point I am genuinely pleased to see that in neither Senator Stone's motion nor his speech is there any reference to the voodoo supply-side theory which was being peddled by the Opposition during the election campaign. Of course, the most virulent form of snake oil was peddled by the Queensland branch of the National Party of Australia, of which ironically Senator Stone is a member. So I hope that is an indication of a lasting change in attitude by the Opposition and the intrusion of a significant amount of reality into its perceptions of the world.

Whilst I can understand that Senator Stone is not eager to remind people of things that were said by various people some time ago, I am afraid I must disappoint him. Indeed, the substance of the case that Senator Stone made-I think this is a completely fair assessment-is that Australia has a pre-existing economic problem, that is, a large current account deficit. He asserts, and there is certainly less agreement on this, that the decline in share prices over the last week or so has seriously aggravated that problem. I believe it remains to be seen whether it has seriously aggravated that problem. But nobody denies that Australia has a large current account deficit, and that that has imposed economic problems on us. In 1981, in an address to the Agricultural Outlook Conference, which was subsequently published in the Quarterly Review of the Rural Economy, which used to be known, I think, as the Bureau of Agricultural Economics Quarterly Review, Senator Stone-and this is in the context of the 1980-81 fiscal year-said:
The current account deficit in 1980-81 is therefore likely to be significantly larger than earlier suggested. This fortunate development-
that is, a blow-out in the current account deficit, described then by Senator Stone as a fortunate development-
will, of course, work to supplement domestic savings.

I am not reviving that quotation just to poke fun at Senator Stone, but because the implications of it are actually much more important. In that period the resources boom was soaring, prior to the wings falling off it, or perhaps some people may argue that it had already soared and it was starting to come down. The damage done by the resources boom hype, firstly, to the expectations of Australians and, secondly, because of the very large overseas debt that was incurred as a result, in anticipation of a major boom, is the origin of the economic problem that this Government inherited, which was subsequently aggravated by the collapse of export prices in 1985 and 1986.

We all know that particularly culpable in beating up the expectations of the resources boom which never happened were the then Treasurer, Mr Howard, the then Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Lynch, the then Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, Mr Anthony, Mr Sinclair, and indeed just about everybody who had a prominent position in the government of the day. What is probably less well known, and which again is evident from the address that Senator Stone gave to the Agricultural Outlook Conference in 1981-and in general it certainly was an interesting address, although I thought some of his answers to questions were better, but unfortunately they were not printed in this article-is that Senator Stone himself had a role to play in beating up the resources boom hype. I quote:

Significant also is the scope for this strengthening in the growth of private consumption to continue beyond the current financial year. The investment upsurge now gathering pace, which will be concentrated in some of the most productive areas of the economy, should, in the first instance, provide scope for growth in real wages and incomes in those areas. It will also duly produce some reshaping of Australian industry-with beneficial consequences for overall national productivity and real income-as the proportion (at least) of our national resource bogged down in less productive areas begins to diminish under the pressures of these developments.

That was certainly beating up expectations of increases in real incomes. In other words, Senator Stone, although his language certainly was much more restrained than the vapid propaganda that was pouring out of the mouths of all other people I mentioned at the time, was accepting the basic proposition, that is, that the resources boom would usher in a new golden era for Australia. Well the boom never really happened, but we have the hangover of that binge still in servicing the huge amount of foreign debt that was incurred in following the so-called boom through. Indeed, as I am sure Senator Stone knows very well-these figures get revised from time to time-after the end of the 1981-82 financial year the current account deficit was assessed at 6.1 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP), the highest it has ever been.

I turn now to the motion. These are technical points, but not entirely unimportant. There is a reference to the United States having a current account deficit as a proportion of GDP of 3.3 per cent. That is the estimate for this financial year. The figure for the first half of this financial year was 3.5 per cent of GDP; in other words, that is probably a bit low. Probably more importantly, to juxtapose that with the Australian gross domestic product is to ignore the fact that the statistics of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, which appear to be the source of those figures, are not comparable with Australian figures because they exclude the liabilities payable in currencies other than United States dollars, and appear to include some equity-type liabilities. In other words, they are compiled on a different basis from the Australian national accounts.

Paragraph 2 refers to the fact-and it is a fact-that such a major change as the collapse of, or a very big decline in, the prices of shares in the last couple of weeks `may have adverse consequences for the prices of our major export commodities'. There is no dispute about that from the Government side; it may indeed have those consequences. It will be some time before anybody actually knows whether that has happened. There is no evidence yet that that will happen. If or when it does happen the Government naturally will have to take that into account, as over the last couple of years the Government has taken into account the massive decline in export prices which took place in 1985 and 1986.

The final paragraph calls upon the Government `as an urgent first step . . . to introduce a mini-Budget directed at significantly cutting Government expenditure'. I find that a little odd coming from the Opposition. Indeed, I suggest that no credibility should be given to it at all until the Opposition clarifies its position on some of its promises to increase spending. For example, is the Opposition still committed to throwing 500 million taxpayer dollars at building a railway from Alice Springs to Darwin? That policy has never been formally repudiated.

In Senator Stone's own State and in his own Party there is a Mr Katter, the son of the member of the House of Representatives and a member of the Queensland Parliament, who every time he is given the opportunity up in northern Queensland babbles on about the need to proceed with the Bradfield scheme. The Bradfield scheme, as I mentioned the other day, is a proposal to dam the coastal flowing rivers in northern Queensland, to dig a tunnel through the Great Dividing Range and to divert the water into the Thomson River and some of the other rivers and, according to the proponents of the scheme, fill Lake Eyre and change forever the climate of Australia. The catch in the scheme, of course, is that, in order to dam a significant amount of water, the altitude at which that must be done requires the water to be pumped up about 1,000 feet before it gets turned back inland. Mr Katter continues, notwithstanding that fact, to describe this Bradfield scheme, which is a sort of fairies at the bottom of the garden or Queensland redneck National Party proposition, as a magnificent scheme to change the climate of inland Australia, to drought-proof Queensland and to generate electricity. There are a number of other technical faults in the proposal such as the fact that, even if the water were impounded and turned backwards, it would not get anywhere near Lake Eyre.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I know that you are quite naturally and quite properly very indulgent of speakers on both sides of this House in a debate of this kind and allow them to range quite widely, but I suggest to you that the matters which the Minister is now addressing have nothing to do not merely with his own responsibilities or those of this chamber but with the motion before the chamber.
—There is no point of order.

—That is absolutely correct, Mr Acting Deputy President. Indeed, this matter is indeed part of my ministerial responsibility. More directly, it is Mr Kerin's or Mr Morris's ministerial responsibility, but, as Minister for Finance, I have a ministerial responsibility for all demands on Commonwealth funds, and there is a Commonwealth water resources program. This Queensland National Party scheme to make water run uphill and generate electricity along the way has the vociferous and impassioned support of at least one Minister in the Queensland State Government. The sorts of people who would believe, of course, that water will run uphill and generate electricity while it is doing so are the sorts of people who believe that one can put a fusion reactor in the boot of a motor car, that Milan Brych had a cure for cancer and that Dr Shrian Oskar was not a crook. In other words, they are all the same sorts of people-they are the Queensland National Party. If Senator Stone is serious about pursuing demands to reduce wasteful public expenditure, I suggest to him that he ought to start with his colleagues in the Queensland National Party. I know he has a difficult task because, firstly, he needs to educate them about such technical realities as those I have mentioned. Senator Stone is well qualified to do this because he started his student life as a physicist-indeed, I think he got a degree as a physicist-so would know very well that one cannot fit a fusion reactor in the boot of a motor car. He would also know that water does not run uphill, let alone generate electricity while it is doing so. So I suggest that he start the educative program not by preaching to people who do not need it but by preaching to those who very clearly do, that is, his Queensland National Party colleagues.

SPEECH.PARA: Just to go through a by no means exhaustive list of the various promises to increase expenditure which various assorted front bench spokespeople of the Opposition have come out with, I cite firstly the restoration of defence cuts. That was called for by Peter White, the shadow Defence Minister. That would cost $350m. There was also the abolition of the means test on age pensions, conservatively costed at $300m a year. There was the restoration of road funding after cuts-at a cost of $180m. I get lobbied by and I get letters from assorted backbenchers and frontbenchers of the Opposition demanding that the Government spend more money on this and that. Only last week we had Senator MacGibbon demanding that some junket for politicians taking trips to the United Nations, or something like that, be restored, at a cost, I understand, of $100,000. In other words, we are surrounded by all these demands to increase government spending, emanating in the main from the very same people who, when they use the other fork of their tongue, say that there is an urgent demand to cut back on government expenditure.

Senator Stone quoted part of an answer that I had given to a question last week. The question had suggested, implied or asserted-I am not too sure now which of those words would be the most accurate-that, because there was a chrono- logical coincidence of the stock market collapse of 1929 and the Depression of the 1930s, the same sort of thing was going to happen again. One could speak for half an hour about this subject, but there are several very profound differences between 1929 and now. One such difference is that in 1929 the Depression probably was not caused by the stock market crash. But leaving that aside, the United States was running a major current account surplus instead of a current account deficit as it has been doing under the Reagan Administration. Another difference is that governments these days have a propensity to intervene if a financial crisis develops, which in the past governments did not have.

Senator Stone thinks that that is a pretty terrible thing. Far from being welcome, he believes that it is dreadful that governments should intervene if and when there is a financial crisis. Certainly intervention can be pushed too far to the point where the stick of the capitalist system-that is, bankruptcy for bad management-no longer applies. It would be unhealthy if governments were to bail out all incompetent managers, although again there are frequent demands from the National Party that that should be done. But there is a very big difference between that and governments moving in via the Reserve Bank of Australia, as is the established pattern in Australia, to ensure that trading banks do not become illiquid. The Reserve Bank stands behind them.

I thought Senator Stone would have known a little of economic history. There was, I think in 1893-certainly it was in the early 1890s-just such a financial crisis in south-eastern Australia in particular. The damage that that financial crisis did in the State of Victoria compared with New South Wales was immense. In New South Wales the Government intervened; in Victoria the Government did not. Even though Senator Stone is known to have some old-fashioned views about a number of things-I am sure he would not deny that-I really am surprised at the implicit rejection by him of the lender of last resort facilities which are provided by the Reserve Bank for all Australian trading banks and which, of course, were not available at all in the financial crisis of the 1890s; and nor were they available in 1929 or 1930, apart from the fact that the Reserve Bank per se did not exist at that time.

In conclusion, I genuinely welcome-even though I do not agree with the Opposition's assumptions-the fact that the Opposition is actually addressing in this motion the things that matter instead of chasing voodoo, supply-side theory about tax cuts down every blind alley.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting the urgency motion today although for considerably different reasons from the ones that were expounded by Senator Stone. I am quite sure that neither side of this chamber will find that at all surprising. The motion moved by Senator Stone on behalf of the Opposition expresses its concern about a number of economic factors which have contributed to Australia's current economic predicament. They include three items in the first point of Senator Stone's motion relating to, firstly, our foreign debt as a percentage of Australia's gross domestic product (GDP); secondly, our current account deficit; and, thirdly, the level of business fixed investment.

SPEECH.PARA: The motion ignores other factors contributing to our current predicament such as the tendency by this Government and other governments, for example, to encourage a move away from equity to debt financing and the deplorable tendency of the so-called private sector to hold the Government to ransom when things do not go its way, something which we would never tolerate from the union movement. For example, I refer to last year's little frolic by the private banking sector in demanding from the Government either that it lift the ceiling on housing interest rates or that it pay the private banking sector some several hundred million dollars by way of compensation in order to prevent it from withdrawing completely money from housing loans. That sort of situation has done nothing much to contribute to a sound and solid financial situation in this country.

Senator Stone's motion also ignores the fact that the stock market-the most free market force of all free market forces-has had its own impact on the economy over the last few years and I suggest that it has not been for the better. Worse, Senator Stone's motion ignores the fact that much of the problem we see today has been caused by the increasingly deregulated system that has operated here and overseas and which has fuelled the alternately greedy and then massively panicky behaviour by some of the world's wealthiest men and the companies they own.

Senator Stone, in his motion, condemns the Government for the fact `that Australia's gross foreign debt, at around 40 per cent of gross domestic product, is now among the highest in the world and compares with a figure of 13 per cent in the case of the USA'. Australia's gross external debt is very high. At the end of June 1987 it was about $110 billion. However, what is very infrequently pointed out by commentators and speakers on this issue is the fact that the private sector debt is almost $66 billion of our gross external debt; that is, about 60 per cent of it. Senator Walsh in his contribution has already pointed out that this started in quite a significant manner with private company borrowings overseas beginning under the Fraser regime when there was talking up of a resources boom going on across the board from that sector of government and in some parts of the private sector. It has risen to horrific proportions since then very largely because the tax system encourages debt financing, as I said a moment ago, rather than equity financing. In particular, the current Hawke Government-I would have thought this was quite contrary to its ideological basis-continues to allow private companies to borrow overseas to finance takeovers, many of which are highly unproductive, and to write off as a tax deduction its massive interest payments on the money borrowed. That concession does two things: it increases our foreign indebtedness and it decreases government revenue through the tax collection system.

I have pointed out in this place on many occasions that we are one of the few countries that do not allow home buyers, for example, to write off their interest payments from their tax liabilities. But the Government does allow private companies to use those interest payments to wipe out the taxable profits-sometimes this applies to almost the entire profits-of the company it takes over and any other company that belongs to its group. It is for that reason-I have said this time and again in this place-that some of the biggest companies in Australia are paying an effective tax rate of around 10, 11 or 12 per cent, something that very few private individuals can hope to do.

Senator Stone castigated the Government because Australia's current account deficit in the balance of payments, which is the source of this growing debt, was forecast in the Budget Papers at $11.5 billion or 4 per cent of GDP in 1987-88 compared with a figure of 3.3 per cent in the case of the United States. Certainly our current account deficit is disastrously high and action has to be taken to correct it. For example, we could start by reducing some of the hundreds of millions of dollars that we spend on unnecessary imports either by wiping them out altogether or by imposing some form of luxury tax on them. Currently, for example, we import several hundred million dollars worth of such exotica as caviar, cat food, champagne and exotic fish. I am sure that we could all live quite nicely indeed without a lot of those items and improve our balance of payments in doing so.

As I have already indicated, we should also outlaw negative gearing for foreign borrowing when it results in a large outflow in interest payments to foreign lenders. We ought-I understand the Government is at least considering this-to tax superannuation funds on the profits they make when they invest overseas. There is currently no incentive for the big life and superannuation funds to invest on-shore when they get the same tax concessions if they invest off-shore. They can speculate in the Aussie dollar to their heart's content and deny Australian development the access it needs to that investment source.

Senator Stone made the final point in the first part of his urgency motion that our level of business fixed investment is low. This is at least in part because too many Australian companies have become speculators in shares and foreign currency dealings. Too much money is being borrowed merely to inflate the value of shares or to speculate against our currency rather than to invest in plant and equipment, to create goods and services which can increase our exports or reduce our dependency on imports. I remind the Senate of some comments that appeared in yesterday's Times on Sunday which quoted Keynes regarding speculating in this way. He made the point, and it is as valid now as it was when he made it, that:

Speculators may do no harm as bubbles on a steady stream of enterprise. But the position is serious when enterprise becomes a bubble on a whirlpool of speculation. When the capital development of a country becomes a by-product of the activities of a casino, the job is likely to be ill-done.

That casino mentality is something we have certainly experienced here and elsewhere in the last week or so. No doubt business confidence will be at an all time low following the stock market meltdown, so to speak. We therefore need government action to direct investment into housing, education and the creation of export and import competing industries, industries which are labour intensive and highly productive.

I note in passing that, in this litany of comparisons between the United States and Australia, Senator Stone left out the fact that our Budget deficit as a percentage of GDP is considerably lower than that of the United States. In 1986-87 it was one per cent of GDP compared with the United States Budget deficit of 4 per cent. This is a clear indication that the level of the deficit has little impact on the market despite insistence to the contrary from the business sector in recent years. Indeed, despite the expenditure cuts which helped to balance our Budget this year having a disastrous effect on low income families and individuals, the stock market meltdown that occurred last week was as bad in Australia as elsewhere, if not worse. So all the arguments from the private sector that if only the deficit were reduced confidence would be restored have come to very little.

Of course this Government should, as Senator Stone has indicated, be speeding up the pace of economic adjustment but not in the way, I suggest, that the New Right proponents of economic rationalism are proposing. For a start, this Government has to put a stop to the very actions that have led to the problem now confronting us. It must put a stop to foreign borrowings by the private sector, and put an end to the lemming-like rush from equity financing to debt financing. In other words, it has to implement policies that motivate long term productive investment instead of short term profit taking in such non-productive areas as the stock exchange and the futures market.

The first step, then, is to abolish negative gearing on both foreign borrowings and money borrowed to speculate-and it is speculation; it is no longer any form of serious investment when we are talking about people borrowing simply to speculate in the share market. The second step that the Government has to take is to further limit foreign investment in Australian companies, restricting that investment to minority shareholdings in ventures which will increase productive capacity. Our stock market falls were significantly greater than those in New York, London and Tokyo, I suggest, at least in part because foreign investors immediately sold their Australian share holdings as a first panic measure largely because, as Senator Stone has already pointed out, the Hong Kong market was closed to them. Asian investors, in particular, could not sell their Hong Kong shares in order to reduce their equity portfolios and turned instead to the Australian market because the much vaunted free enterprise Hong Kong market was closed down. Again, as Senator Stone has pointed out, when that market did open there was something like a 30 per cent fall in the first day's trading-a greater fall in Hong Kong than we experienced in the whole of last week.

The third step is for the Government to inject more money rather than less into the economy, in particular, into the development of export and import replacement goods as well as into research and development. It must do this in conjunction with similar investment from the private sector, which brings me to the second paragraph of the urgency motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —The penultimate paragraph is the one reducing expenditure, not increasing it.

—Certainly major changes to the world economy will adversely affect Australia's economy, but to suggest that our export commodities will fall in price in isolation, and hence cause an additional problem, is a nonsense. If our exports are affected, it is highly likely that everybody else's will be, too. I remind the Senate that other people's exports are in many instances Australia's imports, and if things go in that direction world-wide our balance of trade figures may well improve. In any event, the Government should be looking at those assumptions and conventional wisdoms which have led us to this state of affairs. We have to acknowledge that there are no longer economic certainties and that we should be severely restricting private sector borrowings and increasing government revenue in order to finance those areas of need.

SPEECH.PARA: I picked up the comment from Senator Collins that the second part of this matter of urgency refers to cutting government expenditure. What I am saying is that we should be increasing government revenue and then increasing expenditure in certain areas that are labour intensive. The Labor Government has denied almost every one of its ideological commitments, and if it thinks that by pursuing the sorts of practices instigated by the previous Fraser Government it has not contributed to the economic climate that we see today, it is very much mistaken indeed.

SPEECH.PARA: The basics of our economy are sound.
Only a week ago Paul Keating said:

Let me say, in terms of the adjustments that Australia is making, that as a result of this Government's changes Australia is better placed to face whatever international conditions may come its way . . .
We have these sorts of statements continually. The Treasurer was asked:
What sort of effect will (the stockmarket crash) have on Australia's economy?
Mr Keating replied:
Well I think in terms of trade and our net export performance I don't think very much.

We see this continual self-satisfaction. Of course, Mr Keating has taken the credit for all the adjustments and all the improvements and is now pretending that there is no risk. But what are other people saying? Is Mr Keating right or is Senator Walsh right? Senator Walsh said:
On the macro situation, Australia is certainly not out of trouble. Indeed I'm a bit worried that the Budget might be oversold . . .
He also said in September-this has been quoted by Senator Stone:

Certainly, if there was another commodity price slide, the International Monetary Fund will be knocking on the door again. And I think we all know what would happen to the welfare sector if we are pushed to that point.
I stress this bit of Senator Walsh's speech:
A country which has a high level of foreign debt and a continuing large current account deficit is a country which has few options.

That is the issue. This Government has few options. As time runs out, the fewer options we will have. But it is not only Senator Walsh who has pointed out the realities in his comments about our going down the Argentinean road. Sir Roderick Carnegie, President of the Business Council of Australia, said:
Australia is not well placed to handle an adverse external shock.
We are having just such a shock. Alan Wood, chief economist with Syntec Economic Services Pty Ltd, has said that economic adjustment is not moving at a fast enough pace. He said:
The deficit could, of course, start to blow out in this setting unless the Government does do some further adjustment because of the losses on the revenue side, which potentially are quite large.
Of course, that is not what Mr Keating said. He said that there was not much effect at all. Senator Evans repeated that parrot fashion because he would not know. Alan Wood went on to say:

What the crash in world markets has done is make that strategy irrelevant. We now have to go to a strategy of much more rapid adjustment in order to try and minimise the impact of this very severe external market crash on us.

That was not a member of the Opposition speaking. The quotes I have read are from experts in the market and in the area of financial management. I mentioned Sir Roderick Carnegie, who is one of Australia's leading businessmen. Dr Neville Norman of Melbourne University has expressed doubts over the ability of the Government to meet revenue forecasts. Dr Norman predicted a revenue shortfall of $500m in the current financial year, getting worse in the year after. In this morning's Sydney Morning Herald Max Walsh said:

And if the Australian Cabinet, when it sits down today, does not realise that the assumptions on which the September Budget was made-especially those applying to business investment and export income-are now inoperable, that now is the time to heed Senator Peter Walsh, then the recession we now face is going to be much worse than it need be.
He said:
A May mini-Budget would be tragically late.
Ross Gittins has also expressed his concerns. He said:
. . . the Indian summer lasted six months: the sky is as cloudy as it ever was. We no longer need to debate whether the Budget should have been tougher and the pace of adjustment faster.
There are more such comments. Mr Des Moore, a former Deputy Secretary to the Treasury, said:

. . . the Budget is most disappointing not only because of its pursuit of a high risk economic strategy but also because it has missed the opportunity, open to a new Government in its first term, to make much greater progress in reducing Australia's underlying structural problems. The Budget papers acknowledge that ``a good deal of the task remains ahead and virtually all assessments point to a long hard haul''. A less ``gradualist'' adjustment strategy would have still allowed economic activity and employment to increase through greater adjustment on external account but would have avoided the now extremely risky approach of a dash for growth in domestic spending combined with little, if any, external account improvement.
Professor Arndt posed the question:
What if the confidence should wane? . . . while capital keeps coming in we can finance the current account deficit, balance the Budget and let the stock market set ever-higher records.
That was prescient. He went on to say:
But what if the house of cards collapses.

This Government has indicated to this chamber today that it has no plans whatsoever if the house of cards collapses. It does not even recognise that the house of cards is in danger of collapse. It is still talking about everything being all right at a time when every leading commentator in Australia, when major business people and economists are all saying, `For heaven's sake, you are on the wrong track and the risk is that, as Senator Walsh, a Labor Minister, has said, you will go further down the Argentinean road if you do not take notice of Senator Stone's urgency motion and if you do not introduce as soon as possible a mini-Budget which recognises that the course you as a government are on is the wrong course, that you are not proceeding fast enough and that there is a major and urgent need to change'. Of course, this is exactly what the Opposition has been saying ever since the Budget was brought down.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing a very long-winded matter of urgency introduced by Senator Stone today. It reflects the coalition's confusion on economic matters. It reflects the compromises that have been a characteristic of the coalition since before the last election. It offers nothing new as far as the problems that this country faces at present are concerned. Indeed, it recommends the same old tired cliches in that it says that we should `undertake urgently measures to speed up the pace of the economic adjustment' and, of course, it calls ritually, as the Opposition does, for us to cut government expenditure and reduce total public sector borrowing.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, as has been shown earlier today by Senator Walsh, the Opposition is always calling for cuts in government expenditure until specific members of the National Party of Australia go back to their electorates and demand more from the Government. Senator Stone happens to be privileged to be a member of a party that is notorious for having its snout in the public trough. So that is the background to yet another proposal put up by the coalition.

What we should do first is to think for just a moment about which policies the Opposition is following. We just had a contribution from an honourable senator who was famous in the last election for presenting Opposition policy. He is no longer on the front bench because he did not get it right. So, this is from the titular head of the Liberal Party as from next Friday. This is his prescription-not mentioned in the urgency motion put by the Opposition today, but very significant. Of course, we must understand Mr Elliott's form. I think he was adequately described in the Times on Sunday on 9 August 1987 in relation to a comment made on his pedigree as far as these matters are concerned. An editorial entitled `Corporate tax avoidance-a major scandal' commenced as follows:
The avoidance of taxation by some of Australia's leading entrepreneurial companies is becoming one of the biggest fiscal scandals of the 1980s.
The editorial further stated:

Elders IXL's percentage of tax to profit is getting lower every year. A leading securities firm, Prudential Bache, estimated that in 1988 Elders would pay 8.45 per cent of its before-tax profit in tax, against Paul Keating's nominal rate of 49 per cent. That would be one way of celebrating the bicentenary-as a nation of tax avoiders.

So, the Liberal Party is being influenced by people such as Mr Elliott, who this week is urging people to buy shares and who next week will be telling the Liberal Party to introduce a consumption tax. Whether in relation to the National Party and its flat tax policy or the Liberal Party's hidden proposals for a consumption tax, the problem is that we cannot get an answer from the coalition on what should be done in this country and, indeed, no one can believe that the coalition has any answers to the serious problems that exist-and nobody denies that there is a serious world crisis at this very moment.

The first part of the urgency motion indicates an unfavourable comparison made by the Opposition between the United States and the Australian economies, in comparing gross foreign debt, current account deficit in the balance of payments and levels of business fixed investment. I believe that it is quite ludicrous to make the automatic comparison between the most powerful economy in the world and the Australian economy. However, I will be very happy subsequently to go through that comparison, because one of the significant things that I think we might have seen in this debate, especially when Senator Stone, I think, distanced himself from the Reagan Administration, is that the New Right of politics in Australia is starting to distance itself from President Reagan, the person who has implemented New Right policies in the world. Next, honourable senators opposite will be criticising Margaret Thatcher and distancing themselves from her as well. That is the situation at present. Of course, Senator Walsh has mentioned the New Right supply-side voodoo economics of those leaders referred to, but until this week they have been strongly supported by the New Right people, one of whom, clearly, is Senator Stone.

The Opposition members have found it difficult to distance themselves from their pedigree, which I think is a recent pedigree. Prior to the last election Mr Howard and the Liberal Party proposed that the way in which we should respond to a fall in our terms of trade and our national income was by means of unfunded tax cuts-the very policy which is at the heart of the problem in the United States of America where President Reagan has not been prepared to tax wealthy people. Indeed, he has given them tax cuts. President Reagan has put into effect the policy that the Liberal Party advocated before the last election. Of course, such action would have blown out the Budget in Australia, as it has blown out the Budget in the United States, and, had that Liberal Party policy been introduced, although it would have given a false lift initially to our standard of living, it would have given us the same crisis that has occurred in the United States. President Reagan has in fact believed that a country need not pay for the things that it was buying and using and that another generation could pay for those things. Those chickens have come home to roost in the United States. I hope that subsequently I will have time to draw to the attention of the Senate the matter of how President Reagan is culpable in the economic crisis. As a New Right leader, President Reagan is a person that the coalition has followed, by and large, right up until this very week.

Commodity prices are referred to in the motion and reference is made to infrastructure. The Liberal Party and the National Party want us to cut infrastructure, yet the very crisis that prevails is, as other speakers have pointed out, very much as a result of the talking up of the mineral boom previously. It is the result of the coalition being prepared in the past to be absolutely irresponsible and, of course, the Liberal and National parties have not been prepared to acknowledge what this Government has done.

In concluding my remarks I would like to remind the Senate that the Government has made a $7 billion permanent structural change in the balance of payments, coming from three years of net export contributions, and a 10 per cent decline in real unit labour costs, with a Budget deficit of nearly 5 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP) brought to zero. That is the position at this moment. The Australian Labor Party has been able to implement a wages policy. It is incredible that the Opposition should refer to wages. I think at one stage Senator Stone made a disparaging comment about `our union mates'; however, I point out that it is because of the trade union movement in this country and because of the attitude that this Government has to equity of sacrifice that we have co-operation throughout Australia in an attempt to ensure that we improve our position. We cannot afford the anarchy that Senator Stone represents, if he were to get his hands on the treasury bench. That anarchy can occur at any level, and we see in the United States today, under President Reagan, an anarchy, and that is even when a New Right leader is in charge of government. Although Senator Stone appeared today to be distancing himself from President Reagan, the reality is that President Reagan did not act when he should have acted, and the present circumstances are the inevitable result of his inability to act in this area. Of course, as a conservative leader he is leaving everything to the market. His New Right philosophy involves cutting social welfare, and he has established a record in doubling the deficit in five years. He has increased the armaments bill in the United States to 29 per cent of the budget. He has done all these things without paying for them and, of course, he has pushed the American deficit through the roof which has caused a tremendous crisis for all the Third World countries, indeed, he is the precipitator of this current crisis.

This Government has presided over a situation in which the deficit as a proportion of GDP has been reduced from 8 per cent in 1983-84 to 2.2 per cent this year. We have seen manufacturing investment grow by 4.75 per cent in 1986-87. This development of manufacturing investment is very important. Currently conservative people in this country are talking about business tax. Business tax was equivalent to 30.3 per cent of our GDP in 1985, compared with the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) average of 37.2 per cent. Australia's deficit in 1985 was the third lowest of all OECD countries, and the deficit has been reduced significantly since then.

Those are just some of the figures that show that this Government is very responsible, that this Government has taken steps, and will continue to take steps, in a situation where it has the confidence of the people. We do not represent a narrow group of individuals, such as the John Elliotts of the world, who are the almost faceless people now and who cause the coalition to lurch from crisis to crisis. This Government will continue to consult all of the people in the community. We will listen to business people and to the trade union movement, because we do not have a hangup about the two million wage and salary earners and because we know that their contribution to the nation's economy is vital if we are to get over the world crisis that we currently face.

SPEECH.PARA: I can clearly recall that after the 1986 Budget many people in the financial community and some commentators and others, certainly those in the business community, argued strongly that the Government should immediately after that Budget-the Budget of a year ago-introduce a mini-Budget to repair the omissions of that 1986-87 Budget. This Family Law Council report entitled `Access-Some Options for Reform' cannot possibly be dealt with in the short time available today. I wish to refer briefly to some matters contained in it and I hope that the debate will then be adjourned so that the full import of the matters raised can be discussed. The question of access to children of a marriage which has failed is one of magnitude. There are frequently problems between the parents over what should occur. There are occasions, of course, when the access and custody arrangements work quite smoothly. I would not ever want to see any legislation interfere with the arrangements which parents make for themselves and their children. Such arrangements are the best possible arrangements. This comment was also made in the debate we had not long ago on the matter of maintenance for children: the best arrangements, given that a marriage has failed, are the arrangements which are made amicably between the parents of the children. But it is recognised, of course, that in the areas of maintenance and access there are considerable difficulties in reaching agreement. The report starts off with a summary of conclusions and recommendations. Paragraph 1.1 says:
The Council considers that legislative direction is needed to counteract the notion that a non-custodial parent has a prima facie right of access to her/his child(ren).

Mr Acting Deputy President, I think you would find that in the community there is a very widely held belief that the non-custodial parent has a right to access to his or her children. If we are to contemplate legislation to implement this recommendation the matter will need to be discussed widely in the community and be understood by people before any legislation is debated. It is a matter of such importance that a very wide comprehension by the public is necessary.

Throughout this report there are references to the need for increased counselling. That issue would not be in dispute but I would remind honourable senators about the actual cost of counselling. Unless the Government is prepared significantly to increase the resources available for counselling we really are precluded from some of the changes which may be desirable, because without the availability of increased counselling we may in fact cause far more problems than we attempt to solve. In talking of the cost of counselling the thought comes to my mind that we spend so much in dealing with marriages that have failed but so little on attempting to keep marriages together. There was an incident recently where the Canberra Marriage Counselling Service Incorporated had difficulty in organising new premises. I am pleased to note that the Government has assisted and that it will be able to move and continue its work. There is a very great disproportion between the resources spent on attempting to help marriages before they finish up in the Family Court and the enormous costs of dealing with them once they do. As I said, mention of the need for increased counselling appears throughout this document.

Another recommendation suggests that access agreements between parents should be capable of being registered in a similar way to that in which maintenance agreements may be registered. That, again, picks up the point that I made earlier that the best arrangements are the ones that the parents make for themselves. Paragraph 5.5, headed `Access and child maintenance', states:
This Council is strongly opposed to any connection between the payment of child maintenance and access, even if limited to a mitigating factor as recommended by the ALRC.

We can stand here and talk for a long time about there being no relationship between access and maintenance. The no fault concept was legislated out but we cannot expunge it from the mind of man. DEBATE.TITLE: PRIMARY INDUSTRY BANK OF AUSTRALIA LTD

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

In moving this motion to the 1986-87 annual report of the Primary Industry Bank of Australia Ltd (PIBA) I will make a few remarks on both the bank and the problems facing our primary industries sector at the moment. We should note that in May 1987 the Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced the Government's willingness to sell its interest in the Primary Industry Bank of Australia. On 30 June the Rural and Industries Bank of Western Australia acquired the Commonwealth's share in the Primary Industry Bank. Some three months later, on 18 September, the Government introduced legislation to repeal the various Primary Industry Bank of Australia Acts. This sets a dangerous precedent for a Government intent on privatising Australia's public enterprises. It is the sell first and legislate later mentality. In this case I think it is worth drawing the attention of the community to what has happened.

The Primary Industry Bank of Australia was also granted an unrestricted banking authority which makes PIBA Ltd the seventh largest banking organisation in Australia. We have yet to see whether the new PIBA will be able to assist Australian rural producers who are struggling with low export prices, high interest rates, predatory multinationals and foreign investors. All of these factors are tragically forcing Australian farmers off their farms. The Australian Democrats believe that any primary industry or rural bank should actively involve itself in schemes to alleviate the appalling economic situation faced by a growing number of farmers in particular. The situation for many is desperate.

Debt levels by farmers have tripled in the last decade. A report by the National Australia Bank Ltd earlier this year calculated that there were some 4,000 bankrupt farmers, that 6,000 could survive with special assistance while a further 17,000 faced failure. In 1985-86 the average farmer received a net farm income of some $6,700, not a magnificent income. While the figure for this financial year is expected to be higher than that figure, the rate of return to capital and management will still be a negative 6.9 per cent. There is a great deal of dedication within the farming community which is not clearly recognised when so much capital is placed in an industry which does not return a financial benefit to the people whose capital is invested in it. About 30 per cent of Australian farmers are expected to record negative farm incomes this year.

Apart from the economic effects which farmers and the nation in general experience, there are also harmful social effects on farmers, their families and their communities. One of those effects is an alarming incidence of suicides, particularly by the farmers-a matter which does not draw enough public attention. The Australian Democrats believe that as well as the financial support that can be given, agriculture in this country needs new directions on what types of farming could be undertaken. I draw the attention of the Senate to the enormous support which is given for the primary industry sector in Canada, for instance, which is subsidising farmers to encourage transformation to sustainable agriculture-organic, biodynamic, ecological, biological and chemical free agriculture-and to look to the future, to new markets which are in great demand. That is happening in New Zealand and Australia will again fall behind if it does not happen here. Consumers are looking at the health and environmental aspects of chemical free farming and we should be picking that up in Australia.

For a long time the Australian Democrats have called for subsidised interest rates and for using capital which should be provided by the superannuation funds which are now making big money by sending money off-shore. We also think that statutory reserve deposits should be freed up to provide low interest loans for farmers. There is a big challenge ahead for the Primary Industry Bank and the question is whether that challenge will be met.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The speeches read as follows-
SEA INSTALLATIONS BILL 1987

Passage of this legislation is necessary so that a regulatory system is in place in time for the opening of the floating hotel to be installed at the John Brewer Reef by Barrier Reef Holdings, and to consider proposals for other similar ventures.

There have been several proposals for establishing off-shore installations on the continential shelf beyond the territorial seas, mostly, to date, in the Great Barrier Reef area. Some of these can be dealt with under existing arrangements involving the Great Barrier Reef Ministerial Council and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, both of which involve continuing Commonwealth and Queensland cooperation on policies and day to day management. However, proposals are now being made which require regulation beyond the scope of those arrangements.

This legislation provides a framework to ensure that new developments are technically sound and environmentally acceptable. It also provides a basis for the application of important Commonwealth laws in an area of Commonwealth responsibility where presently no general body of civil or criminal law applies, and for State or Territory laws to be adopted as Commonwealth laws.

These provisions are parallel to those already applying under the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act, which regulates off-shore petroleum and mineral exploration and extraction. That Act and the Bills are based on the belief that the most efficient approach is to adopt State and Territory laws and to develop administrative arrangements involving State and Territory administrations. This approach also takes account of the satisfactory arrangements we have with the Queensland Government for day to day management of Great Barrier Reef Marine Park activities by the Queensland National Parks and Wildlife Service.

It is important that off-shore installations not be used as a basis for evasion of Australian laws, particularly those regulating customs, migration, taxation and quarantine. The proposed legislation will deal with this by requiring contact with the installations to be from the mainland or an adjacent territory, and by including provisions to ensure that the laws in question can be efficiently and effectively applied. The Bills do not cover sales tax and income tax, both of which will be the subject of separate legislation in accordance with the Treasurer's announcement in January this year.

The approach taken in the legislation is to require proponents of off-shore installations to seek permits. They will have to provide information about the purpose of the installation, structural and technical issues, the extent of use and occupation by people, insurance arrangements and so on so that proper standards can be applied, and assessments made of the impact on the environment. Where necessary, the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act will be invoked, as was done in the case of the proposed floating hotel off Townsville, and is now being done for a similar proposal for the Fitzroy Reef.

Permits will be accompanied by whatever safeguards are necessary to ensure that safety and environment considerations are paramount in day to day operations. Variation, revocation and renewal provisions have been included to provide a means of continuing monitoring and to allow changes to accommodate any new factors which arise. Thus concerns relating to the number of permitted sea installations, particularly tourist complexes, which were raised during the second reading debate earlier this year, are groundless. This Government is not about to authorise a chain of floating hotels in the Great Barrier Reef region, which this legislation is designed to protect.

The application of State laws and the use of State administrations will be an important part of this monitoring, in areas like health standards and others which will normally apply to similar operations on the mainland. The Sea Installations Bill makes clear that the States will be paid for their participation.

There are several categories of installations which do not require further regulation such as certain fishing vessels and historic shipwrecks. These are already subject to effective and sufficient regulation. It will also be possible under the regulations to exempt other installations from the new legislation. A provision has been included to allow exemption from particular aspects of the regulatory scheme.
This will also ensure there is no unintended interference with existing regulatory arrangements directed at matters not within the objectives of this Bill.

On the other hand, care has been taken in defining sea installations to include non-exempted ships which remain constantly or continuously in the seas in question and thereby provide a basis for evasion of the legislation. These provisions acknowledge our obligations in respect of foreign shipping.

Since the original Bill has been publicly available, a number of useful comments have been made leading to some changes. For example, the definition of `sea installation' has been amended to provide for further exemptions from the operation of the legislation, including commercial fishing and pearling vessels, navigational and meteorological aids, commercial cargo carriers, wharves and jetties and historic shipwrecks. These exemptions will ensure further that overregulation will not occur.

The Government has also recognised the desirability of amending the levy arrangement to permit flexible and simple approach. In some cases, a fixed fee based on revenue or market value may be appropriate, while in others a fee based on the number of visitors may be best. This approach recognises the variety of installation, ranging from fairly simple pontoons to large hotels, which may need to be covered.

The development of off-shore installations is already a fact of life. We are committed to harmonising conservation and sustainable development in the natural environment. This includes the seas. This legislation will be part of the Government's policy of protection, wise use, understanding and enjoyment of the environment. This approach is already being applied by the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority to installations subject to its regulations.
I commend this Bill to the Senate.
SEA INSTALLATIONS LEVY BILL 1987
This Bill is part of a package of Bills to provide for the implementation of the Government's decisions relating to sea installations.

The Levy Bill provides a framework for imposing taxes and charges on these installations. This will ensure that the administrative costs of the States and Territories are met, and that general revenue can benefit, as it would if similar installations were located on the mainland. The States have quite rightly pointed out that the development of off-shore installations for commercial purposes should not be at the expense of the mainland economy, and should not provide a basis for evasion of State and Territory legislation. The Commonwealth accepts this, and so the intention is that the levy be set with these factors in mind.
I recommend this Bill to the Senate.
SEA INSTALLATIONS (MISCELLANEOUS AMENDMENTS) BILL 1987
This Bill makes amendments to Commonwealth legislation necessitated by the sea installations legislative package.

The Customs Act 1901 and the Excise Act 1901 are amended to give to officers administering the respective Acts power over such installations, ships, aircraft, persons and goods arriving with or at the installations or departing overseas from such installations.
The Migration Act 1958 is amended to identify the point when sea installations and the persons on board enter Australia and when such installations become or cease to be part of Australia.

The amendments to the Quarantine Act 1908 apply a wide range of controls under the Act to sea installations. The principal control is to make newly-arrived installations, persons and goods on the installations subject to quarantine.
I commend this Bill to the Senate.
