DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN LAND TRANSPORT (FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 21 October, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Land Transport (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill 1987 seeks to amend the Australian Land Transport Act by reducing the amount of excise collected through the Australian Land Transport Program Trust Fund in order to hold the total Federal finance for roads at $1,245m for 1987-88. This is the fourth year in a row that expenditure on roads has been held at that level-the fourth year in a row in which, at a time of rapid inflation, road funding has been held constant in money terms. Since the Hawke Government came to power, spending on roads has fallen by 40 per cent in real terms. This Bill gives effect to an announcement in the May economic statement. As this is a Bill contained in the Budget the Opposition will not be opposing it. However, that will not stop us from making strong condemnation of it, because it is an example-a key example-of the Government's lack of commitment to the measures necessary to get this country out of the mess into which this same Government's reckless mismanagement has plunged it. The Government's own Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, has claimed that there were about 200 government-funded programs that could not be justified on economic or equity grounds. Yet, rather than tackling these sorts of programs, the Government is reducing the amount spent on roads-roads which are vital to the efficient working of our economy.

SPEECH.PARA: Quite apart from the share market collapse last week-it is apparently continuing this week-which will give the Government yet another excuse for the deplorable failure of its economic programs, let us look at what is the real state of our economy, how we are going to get out of our current crisis, and the vital contribution that an improved infrastructure such as better roads would play in any recovery. Our gross foreign debt has risen more than three-fold during the life of the Hawke Government. It is now 40 per cent of gross domestic product, compared with 13 per cent in the case of the United States. We are now the third most indebted country in the world. The causes of this rapidly growing debt during the disastrous years of the Hawke Government has been our current account deficit. For this year, the Government has forecast it will be $11.5 billion-$11,500m-or 4 per cent of our gross domestic product. Under the Hawke regime we have been living recklessly beyond our means, borrowing overseas to maintain a standard of living we are not earning. Not long ago the Treasurer (Mr Keating) was saying how much the economy was growing, how much national spending was going up. Certainly it has been growing, but it has been growing by borrowing overseas. We are like a family which has suffered a loss in income continuing to maintain its previous standard of living by borrowing and claiming proudly that it is spending more than anyone else in the street. That can go on for a while, but eventually the hire purchase debts come in-and the debts for this Government are coming in now.

Certainly we have been heavily hit by the declining terms of trade within the last few years, but it is worth noting that in the first year of the Hawke Government our terms of trade actually improved, and we did not then hear the Hawke Government modestly disclaiming responsibility for the slight recovery there was in 1983. Our declining terms of trade-the fact that we are getting less for our exports-are a fact of life, and there is no short term recovery in sight. We must adjust our lifestyle, our wages policy and our investment policy to cope with these facts of life. This the Hawke Government steadfastly refuses to do.

Let us look at two key areas which we must succeed in if we are to get out of our present economic crisis. Firstly, we must improve our national productivity. Under the Hawke Government, productivity in 1985-86 declined by 1.6 per cent. In 1986-87, there was a further decline of 2.8 per cent. The decline in productivity over the last two years has been about 4.5 per cent. At a time when we are facing a crisis in increasing our exports and import replacement, our national non-farm productivity under the economic management-if that is the right word-of this disastrous Government, has declined by 4.5 per cent. Admittedly the Treasurer promises a small productivity rise this year-but he claimed there was going to be one last year, and there was not. His credibility, except among the parliamentary Press Gallery sycophants, is extremely low-and justly it is extremely low.

If we are going to get out of our economic crisis we must improve our productivity, and a vital element of improved productivity is investment in new plant and equipment and infra- structure. The sad thing is that, despite the devaluation of the Australian dollar and the increased competitiveness in both exports and import replacement which has resulted from that, investment in new plant and equipment has not been forthcoming. There has not been the sharp rise in investment in new plant and equipment without which our recovery cannot be said to have started. Despite the devaluation, the collapse of the Australian dollar, since the Hawke Government came to power investment in new plant and equipment as a proportion of gross domestic product has actually fallen. As I say, this is despite the collapse of the Australian dollar which the economic management of this Government caused. Despite this collapse, businesses have not felt sufficient confidence in the Government's economic policy to invest in new plant and equipment-and the Government has shown its own attitude to investment by reducing real expenditure on roads each year for the last four years. There has been a decline in investment in roads in real terms of 40 per cent since the Hawke Government came to power. These roads, as part of the transport infrastructure, are vital to our national productivity.

One can understand the attitude of private companies to investment when Australia has an inflation rate two or three times that of its trading competitors, when the productivity of workers in the manufacturing sector is falling rather than rising and when company tax in this country is far higher than that of our trading competitors. Faced with such problems, one can understand why businesses are not investing, but how can one possibly justify the Government not investing in the vital infrastructure on which the future prosperity of this country depends? Roads are particularly important in Australia. We have a very large country, with wide distances between our manufacturing centres. The policy of this Government and the arrogant and grossly selfish behaviour of the maritime and waterfront unions have reduced our coastal shipping to a mere shadow of what it ought to be for a country of our nature. Cargoes which under a rational economic analysis should be sent by sea are sent by land instead. Our rail systems are inefficient and overmanned, and excessively costly to the community.

The only efficient form of transport in this country is road transport because it is largely un-unionised. But surely even this Government realises that, if we are to have efficient road transport, we must be prepared to spend money on the road infrastructure. The great crime of this Government is the year by year decrease in the real amount spent on roads. The Treasurer keeps on assuring us that all the economic indicators are on track. That may be true, but what track are they on? I find Mr Keating's remarks like those of the captain of the Titanic assuring the passengers that the ship was on course for New York. Well, it was-but look what happened to it.

Roads are vital to our economy, and it is worth noting how the development of roads has gradually become more and more a Federal responsibility. Under the Constitution, the Federal Government has no responsibility for roads, except in the Territories. Since 1922 the Federal Government has been funding roads. This was challenged in 1926 in the High Court, which upheld the Commonwealth's power to make grants to the States under section 96 of the Constitution on such terms and conditions as it saw fit. The Federal Roads Act 1926 specified that a quarter of the grants was to go for the construction of new roads and three-quarters for the reconstruction and maintenance of existing roads. These roads grants were linked to excise in 1931, but that link was removed by the Commonwealth Aid Roads Act 1959 when funds were made available from consolidated revenue.

Prior to 1969, 80 per cent of Commonwealth assistance went to rural roads. The Commonwealth Aid Roads Act 1969 introduced four categories for road assistance-urban arterial roads, rural arterial roads, rural local roads and planning and research. Nearly 50 per cent of the road grants at that time went on urban arterial roads. Between 1969 and 1977 the Commonwealth Bureau of Roads reports led to assistance being distributed largely on an analysis of economic benefits, the distribution of roads grants being altered to favour the more populous States. This distribution of road money has remained relatively fixed since 1977. With the change of government in 1972, the Commonwealth accepted responsibility for national highways and major commercial roads through the National Roads Act 1974. At the same time a new category-urban local roads-was added. The States Grants (Roads) Act 1977 combined the two Acts of 1974 and the distribution was slightly altered. In 1982 the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund was established to continue until 1989 and to provide funds for national, urban, rural arterial and local roads through a specific excise levy on fuel sales.

There has been a long Commonwealth involvement in road grants and the Bill that is now before the Senate amends the legislation introduced by the Hawke Labor Government in 1985. This Bill amounts to an assault on road funding. Federal road financing in Australia will sink to its lowest level in real terms for many years. Sealed country roads in every State are now being torn up and returned to gravel because insufficient money is available for their maintenance. When Mr Peter Morris, the previous Minister for Transport, introduced the original Bill in 1985, he said:

The Bill now before the House will be the foundation upon which our overall approach to transport will be based. It provides a use related basis for determining Federal expenditure on land transport systems. Furthermore, the arrangements incorporate an automatic adjustment to match future inflationary movements as measured by the consumer price index.
I repeat what the Minister said then:
. . . the arrangements incorporate an automatic adjustment to match future inflationary movements as measured by the consumer price index.

Like most Hawke Labor Government promises, that one has not been kept. The funds have not been increased in accordance with the consumer price index but in real terms have fallen 40 per cent during the time in office of the Hawke Labor Government. So much for Labor's longstanding policy commitment to the improvement of our nation's road system. I hate to think what Labor would be doing if its longstanding policy commitment was to wrecking the national road system. The present Government is doing a very successful job to that end by its policy of underfunding this vital national asset.

In the last four years of the Hawke Labor Government this program has been maintained in dollar terms at $1,245m. In real terms it has been effectively worth about 9 per cent less each year. That is why I say that the drop in real terms in road funding expenditure over the years of the Hawke Government has been 40 per cent. In 1982-83, the last year of the coalition Government, the first year in which the bicentennial road development program had any effect-road funding accounted for 2.12 per cent of total government outlays. Labor Government spending on roads this year is less than 1.6 per cent. The Government is pocketing the difference between the money raised by the 2c levy and the indexed portion of the excise. That is how it balances its Budget. It cuts back on vital infrastructure development, essential expenditure for our national recovery. That is the measure of what this Government is doing.

The Government says that it will save $166m this year by cutting road funding-in other words, by not indexing this year, bearing in mind the fact that it has not indexed in the last three years either. Of this, $67.6m will be saved by running down the reserves in the trust funds established for road programs. These trust funds are being run down-one to zero and the other to two-thirds its present level. What will the Government do next year? It has run down the funds by $67m this year, and it will have only $19m left next year, so where will the extra $50m come from even to maintain the current money value of expenditure on roads?

This neglect of roads is a national disgrace-a disgrace to this Government. Good roads, good transport systems, are vital for our economic efficiency. Everyone who uses roads in Australia suffers from this Government's action. Increased spending on roads and increased investment in the national economy by the Government are essential if we are to return to being an efficient and effective producer and exporter. Proper expenditure on transport infrastructure is vital if we are to get out of our present economic crisis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems as if politicians are constantly talking about roads. This is because roads are the common denominator of our culture. Roads are a measure of how well a government is doing. It is one of the main visible signs of a government that the roads are in good or bad repair. We spent an awful lot of time talking about roads in the Tasmanian Parliament; I did not really think we would spend much time in the Senate talking about roads and up to now we have not. But now we have the topic before us. It is very difficult to give a stimulating speech about roads, but I will give some general observations.

SPEECH.PARA: Like it or not, this is the age of the internal combustion engine and cars and trucks need roads. If we are to have roads we ought to have good roads. Frankly, I would like to see our society restructured to the point where we do not rely so much on the internal combustion engine. Eventually there will come a time when we will run out of fossil fuels and we will get back to mass transport systems, rapid transit and other ways of moving people. But at the moment we have a high dependence on the internal combustion engine and we need the roads.

Consequent upon the May economic statement and the Budget, the Government announced that 1987-88 payments under the Australian land transport program (ALTP) and the Australian bicentennial road development (ABRD) program would be maintained at the same level as last year. In effect, this is a reduction in expenditure on road programs, as Senator Hamer has previously noted. The ALTP was established to replace previous State financial assistance programs for road construction and maintenance. The ALTP is a five-year scheme which will operate until 1990 and is financed through the allocation of a share of the excise on motor spirit and diesel fuel.

Section 14 of the Australian Land Transport (Financial Assistance) Act contains the formula for calculating the proportion of excise that will go towards ALTP. Although the share of excise allocated to the ALTP is supposed to be indexed to the consumer price index, the Government's announcement means a reduction in the rate of excise from 3.964c per litre to 3.241c per litre, applicable from 1 July 1987. The grants to the States under ALTP in 1987-88 represent a reduction of $41.6m on the grants in 1986-87, though this is matched approximately by increased funding under the ABRD program. This effective decrease in expenditure on roads has now occurred over several years, as the Democrats have pointed out before. The ALTP is the only Federal program which provides funds for maintenance and anyone who has travelled on arterial roads-particularly in country areas-would realise how badly maintenance is needed.

One point which must be made relates to the heavy use of roads by trucks-a major factor in the breakdown of those roads. As a society we should move-and I hope the Government is doing so-in the direction of moving as much transport as possible from the highways to the railways. After all, all fuels are subject to this excise tax and it would be good if some of this excise were diverted towards the railways. For moving bulk goods from one major centre to another, the railways have definite advantages as they cover long distances across the country. I know that the railways are looking at various ways of moving containers, such as putting them one on top of the other, but they have problems with bridge heights. I think this is an area in which we should concentrate on removing as much truck traffic from the roads as possible.

The Government has made much of achieving a balanced Budget this year, but running down our vital road system is not an appropriate means to use in achieving this. Apart from the fact that our industries need a well maintained road system, other long term costs will be higher. There will be accidents, causing personal injury and damage to vehicles and these will undoubtedly increase as roads run down. The Federal Government has a clear responsibility in this area, but it has refused to recognise that responsibility in any real sense. The clear trend of road funding-particularly in relation to maintenance of roads-has been downwards since this Government was first elected. Any damage to national road infrastructure is damage to a national asset, and that is to be condemned.

The indexation implicit in the plan has been put aside repeatedly and the Australian Land Transport (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill 1987, like the other Bills before it, will wind back the amount of excise available. This is an awful example of spending priorities and is a clear insight into the importance which this Government places on road funding which, of course, is very low indeed. Despite the disclaimer of the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) in his second reading speech, that these amendments `in no way change the Government's commitment to the development of a road network which will meet Australia's national economic objectives', the Australian people will not be fooled. They have noticed and will continue to observe the deterioration of our road system. Unless this Government reverses the trend, the Australian Democrats will continue to deplore the implications of this Bill. However, the Government is now holding all the cards. If we vote against the Bill the roads will receive no funding at all. Therefore, we reluctantly support the legislation and we hope that in the future the Government takes a good hard look at the road system and gives it the funding that it deserves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to stand here and speak to the Australian Land Transport (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill 1987 because, as an Australian Democrat senator, Senator Sanders, has pointed out, we must support this Bill as it is a piece of Budget legislation. I also want to point out, as my colleague Senator Hamer has, the flaws in the Bill and the lack of support given to roads, particularly Victorian roads. I do not really know why Senator Sanders bothered to speak to this Bill because the Australian Democrats have spent most of their time lying across roads, thus preventing them from being built through the most inaccessible areas, such as in Queensland. The Democrats are the greenest of greenies and they have no interest in roads in Victoria or any part of Australia. I do not think that the Democrats are at all genuine in their response to this Bill. The National Party of Australia has had the most concern for roads right across this country because, as we all know, they are the lifeline of rural Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The debate on the Australian Land Transport (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill has followed a most serious and potent urgency motion moved by the Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate, Senator John Stone. That urgency motion dealt with the whole strategy-or, indeed, the lack of strategy-of this Government's expenditure and Budget priorities. This Bill is a fine example of where it places its priorities. To that extent, this Bill really shows the Government's lack of courage and will, as Senator Stone so clearly pointed out, in relation to the fundamental economic problems. Road funding goes to the heart of the fundamental responsibilities of any government, be it local, State or Federal. This Bill relates directly to the country and rural areas of Victoria, and indeed, of Australia, but being a Victorian senator I have no shame in saying that Victoria is my priority.

Today is a sombre time-as the last week or so has been-for the share markets and the economic welfare of this country. Today we have seen the Hong Kong markets collapse. The Australian market is again unsteady and unnerved. There has been a great need for governments and, indeed, business to get back to the fundamentals, to their real responsibilities from which they have drifted away so much in the past five years of this Government. Too many Government Ministers have been caught up with the high-fliers of business. If one wants to see a row of high-fliers in business, one only has to look at the front page of today's Australian newspaper to see how they are all bailing each other out. These are men whom the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has gone fishing with, has partied with and has changed legislation for. These people who are on the front page of the Australian today are the high-fliers and they are all bailing each other out. What about the small investor and the small businessman who are affected by this Government's policies or lack of policies for them? They now need the attention of this Government so badly, as Senator Stone clearly pointed out in his motion today.

I do not wish to drift too far and wide, but again this Bill is one of the finest examples of how governments must get back to the basic fundamentals of their expenditure. I proudly say that I am a Melbourne City Councillor. For many years the Melbourne City Council has been Labor dominated. So many of the major capital cities have had to suffer Labor-dominated councils. In the Federal, State and local government arenas we have seen Labor-dominated authorities drift far and wide from their basic responsibilities. They have put money into anything that would get them a vote. They have completely wasted the funds of ratepayers and of taxpayers at State and Federal levels on fairy floss schemes which are quite clearly coming undone now that the markets dictate that we should all get back to fundamentals.

Senator Stone was probably too kind to Senator Walsh when he said that he did not believe that it was totally Senator Walsh's fault and that Senator Walsh had made some attempt, pitiful as it was, in Cabinet discussions to sway the Treasurer (Mr Keating). I do not feel as kindly towards Senator Walsh. In my time as a senator I have had to listen to that boring, low key-I ask you, Mr Acting Deputy President, to restrain me before I sink to the depths of the gutter Senator Walsh sinks to, as does his colleague Mr Keating when he calls people scum. They also deserve to be called scum for the state they have put this country in today. It is a great worry, particularly as we enter our bicentennial year.

Our bicentennial year is a time we should reflect and reaffirm our traditional beliefs, our belief in past Australians who have made this country a very fine and great country-pioneers, properly described by Banjo Patterson and Henry Lawson-the people who settled this nation. Yet we are witnessing the collapse of this great nation. I will never let Senator Walsh forget that what he has done to this country is contemptible. It is lower than the lowest thoughts or words that come to my mind. Out of the respect that I have for this chamber I will not sink to the depths to which this man has sunk. He has my utter contempt.

This Bill shows the priorities of this Government, as I have clearly outlined. For the past four years this Government has frozen its expenditure on roads. As Senator Hamer pointed out, there has been a 40 per cent decrease in funding for the lifeline of rural people and, indeed, of all Australians. What a pitiful reflection of this Government's attitude towards rural people. It has been, unashamedly, the National Party's tradition to support the rural people of Australia. They are our roots. We do not deny them, although it should be pointed out that in Victoria we received very broad-based support at the last election. We received many new city votes. That is very much the future of the National Party, although we do not leave our roots behind. In Victoria we received a great deal of new city and country votes. This Bill does not address the great problems of rural Australia and, speaking as a Victorian senator, of rural Victoria.

As I travel across the great State of Victoria the clearest issue that comes across to me is roads and the deterioration of roads. Every council I visited during my campaign, and since my campaign, formed small lobby groups to push the issue, to try to force this Government into greater expenditure on roads. If we are not to be led down the Argentinean road, as Senator Walsh commented in a fleeting moment of honesty and integrity which I daresay has now gone and gone for good, we need to get back to the basics, to the fundamentals, of government and what they are all about.
I believe that the National Party has the finest policy on roads. I quote from what our policy document states we would do upon return to government:
Upon return to government the National Party will ensure that the Federal road finance will equal 6c per litre of fuel excise.
As honourable senators will be aware, the fuel excise now is 20c per litre. We would deliver 6c per litre of fuel excise directly to road funding. The policy document continues:
This would include the 2c per litre on the ABRD levy which is to be continued beyond 1988.

The Australian bicentennial road development program levy is related to bicentennial road funding. I conclude by assuring the people of Australia, and the people of Victoria in particular, that the National Party knows its roots. It knows its foundations. We have never diverged from the fundamentals of government. When re-elected, which I believe will come about at the next election, we will implement our policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking in support of the Australian Land Transport (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill 1987, I must say that I have been rather surprised by some of Senator McGauran's comments. He set out to try to prove how the National Party of Australia was so committed to road funding but seemed to slip up half-way through his speech and say that, in fact, the National Party of Victoria is more concerned with winning votes in the city. I am thoroughly confused. I dare say that many of Senator McGauran's supporters in Victoria are just as confused. Senator McGauran went on to be particularly critical of the Hawke Government and to talk about the Government's neglect of rural areas. In that case, I am not quite sure why the Hawke Labor Government was returned with increased support from rural electorates, particularly in Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: The other thing I would like to raise with Senator McGauran is whether he supports Senator John Stone's proposal of a 25 per cent tax. It is well known that if that National Party policy were adopted-heaven forbid!-programs would be cut in every area of government. We would not be here debating the Australian Land Transport (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill; we would be looking at considerable reductions in government spending and government commitment.

TALK.START.PARA: —And very big increases in private sector spending, Senator.

—I remember that Senator Stone's entire election strategy in Queensland, when he was in Queensland during the election campaign, was based on major cutbacks. I do not have the statement with me, unfortunately, but I remember specific commitments to cut road funding. That shows the hypocrisy that exists in this chamber. We hear one thing out in the electorate just before an election and we hear pious presentations in this chamber when the Government is acting responsibly.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is continuing its road program. It is that continuity that counts. Over the five Budgets brought down by this Government road funding has been 24 per cent higher in real terms than it was for the last five Budgets of the previous Government. Although I guess comparisons would be a little sensitive for members of the Opposition, if they want to make comparisons of Commonwealth road funding as a proportion of Budget outlays, they will find that the average for the five Budgets brought down by this Government is still better than that for the last five Budgets of the previous Government.

Let me just put the three basic arguments. Despite the need to restrain government expenditure in a responsible manner, the Hawke Government is committed to improving our terms of trade and reducing the deficit and overseas debt. Yet the Government has determined that the overall level of road funding will remain the same as in 1986-87. (Quorum formed) As I was saying when the quorum was called, while the Government recognises the importance of developing the nation's transport infrastructure no one could realistically expect road funding to be exempt from the review of major expenditure programs. Indeed, it is something of an achievement to maintain spending at this level. It is all very well for Opposition members to be critical. But where is the money coming from?

The second point was about the Government's record. Federal road funding provided under the five Budgets of the Hawke Government is 24 per cent higher in real terms than that provided under the last five Budgets of the Fraser Government. This funding level has been achieved against a background of a continuous reduction in the Budget deficit from a prospective $10 billion when the Hawke Government came to office in 1983 to the balanced Budget presented by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) last month.

The final argument relates to effort neutrality. Consistent with the recommendations of the Federal Road Funding Inquiry, the Cameron Inquiry, the Federal Government holds the view that the funding of arterial and local roads is basically the responsibility of State and local governments. On this point, Senator McGauran may well like at some time to take up the question of road funding with his colleagues in Queensland. If he is satisfied with the funding levels and the priority given to road funding in Victoria, I suggest he look at the priority given by the Queensland National Party Government to road funding. The Federal Government does not provide top-up funding for these roads, but simply a base level of assistance. The Federal Government is not responsible for funding shortfalls of State and local governments; it is up to State governments to set their priorities. The Queensland National Party Government, as Senator McGauran is probably aware, has some pretty strange priorities.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (GENERAL REVENUE) AMENDMENT BILL 1987STATES (WORKS AND HOUSING) ASSISTANCE AMENDMENT BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 22 October, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The States Grants (General Revenue) Amendment Bill 1987 amends the States Grants (General Revenue) Act to give effect principally to decisions first announced at the Loan Council and Premiers Conference meetings in late May this year. In doing so it carries through the policies of the Government announced at that time. The principal of those policies has been to hold the position of the States so that it is totally incompatible with that of the Commonwealth. We have heard-not so much in recent days but certainly at the time of the Budget-a great deal from the Government about the sharp cut in real terms in total Commonwealth outlays which the Government said it achieved in the Budget for 1987-88. I think I recall correctly that the figure quoted at that time was a cut of 2.4 per cent in real terms. If we leave aside the fact that $1,000m of that was obtained by some fancy footwork on the accounting side and that, in the absence of that amount, the cut in real terms would have been 1.2 per cent, what we then find is-this is the point in this comment-that the whole of the cut was achieved in the area of Commonwealth payments to the States, of which this is by far the most important element. In other words, what we have in this area this year is very much a replay-a somewhat reinforced replay-of what we have had in previous years from this Government and indeed, I add, from previous governments, not merely from this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: We have had a process whereby when expenditure has risen it has risen much more on programs of Commonwealth Ministers than on payments that the Commonwealth makes to the States. When programs have been under some degree of restraint, as they have this year, we have found that that restraint has extended significantly to the States but not to the Commonwealth's own programs. Indeed, I believe I am correct in saying that if we take only the Commonwealth's spending programs, as laid down in the Budget for 1987-88, we find that in fact there was a marginal real increase-not a significant one, nevertheless a slight increase of a decimal point or so-in Commonwealth spending on its own programs in 1987-88 and about a 4.6 per cent cut in real terms, that is, after adjustment for inflation, in Commonwealth payments to the States for expenditure on their programs. As I have said, the single greatest element in that latter area is that with which we are dealing in this Bill.

The Commonwealth has once again said that it is in favour of expenditure restraint. What it really means is that it is in favour of expenditure restraint by somebody else; that it is in favour of expenditure restraint by State governments. I totally agree that there is a need on the part of the Government to restrain spending by State governments and to that extent-and I underline the words `to that extent'-I totally agree with the decisions to that effect made at the May Premiers Conference. Indeed, at that time I served for a couple of days in a special capacity as adviser to the Premier of Queensland. As part of my duties I helped his Treasury to produce at that time a document calling upon the Commonwealth Government to undertake even greater expenditure restraint than proposed and indeed actually concluded by the Commonwealth. But the important qualification, or condition, if you like, which was applied at that time by the Premier of Queensland, and with my full advice, was that this should be done on the basis of the Commonwealth also being prepared to make equal cuts in its own spending-and that, of course, is what signally and quite obviously the Commonwealth has totally failed to do.

Commonwealth Ministers like the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh)-although, to be fair, I will absolve to some degree the Minister for Finance from these particular encomiums-run around this country talking about the restraint in their expenditures, but there is no restraint at all in spending by Commonwealth Ministers on their programs. The only restraint that has been applied in this Budget, leaving aside the fancy footwork on the accounting side, is in the payments being made to the States by the Commonwealth. The fact of the matter is that what we have, once again, is the Commonwealth saying to the States, `Don't do as I do; do as I say'. So, in this Bill the decisions of the Premiers Conference-and those which are incorporated in the Bill are the most important decisions-will again result in the funds to be made available to the States from the Commonwealth being cut very much more sharply than the funds being expended by the Commonwealth on its own programs, which, in fact, are not being cut at all in real terms. That is the Commonwealth's view of fiscal equity as between the Commonwealth and the States.

That process-and we have had a whole progression of it over the years-results in more and more financial power accruing to Canberra. It is, of course, precisely that process to which those on this side of the Senate, and particularly those in the Party from which I come, object most strongly. We object not merely to the size of government that we now have in Canberra, not merely to this whole big government machine which has grown up here over the years-and, I say again, not merely under this Government-but also to the failure to decentralise government out of Canberra. We have not merely very big government in Australia but a very big part of it in Canberra. That is one of the things which is producing the fiscal constipation from which Australia is suffering these days, particularly under the present Government.

Let us look again at the reasons underlying the Government's decision last May to cut substantially the funds available to the State governments, including those in this general revenue area but not confined to it. The rationale underlying that process was that it was desirable to force the State governments to make significant cuts in their expenditures and hence to force them into reducing their demands on the financial markets and to make them reduce their contribution to the total public sector borrowing requirement. What has actually happened, of course, is that in the period since that time all six States have brought down Budgets, and I think that, with only one or two exceptions, they have all shown that they have really paid very little attention to the measures imposed by the Commonwealth at that time.

A very interesting article was produced recently by the States' Policy Unit of the Institute of Public Affairs in Perth, Western Australia, which is headed by a director who was previously the Western Australian Under-Treasurer for many years, Mr Les McCarrey, and who is a highly knowledgeable official, concerning a survey of all those State Budgets. Mr McCarrey undertook a similar survey last year, as a matter of fact, at which time I think he awarded the order of the lemon, as he called it-that is to say, the order given to the least responsible State Government Budget-to the State of Western Australia. This year he has given it overwhelmingly to the State of New South Wales. This year it has not even been a horse race; the State of New South Wales has overwhelmingly received this, I think, rather undesirable award from Mr McCarrey, following his examination of the State Budgets. The reason for that, of course, is that the New South Wales Government is once again trying to play the same old three card trick which it has been playing for years and years and which the present Federal Government has been busily emulating ever since it came into place, in Canberra, namely, spending money that it does not have. We have had a succession of high deficit Budgets, not merely from the present Government here in Canberra but, in particular, from its forebears in New South Wales, one might almost say, given the linkages between the factions of the Labor Party. Once again, that situation pertains this year.

The economic implication of all that-and this is particularly serious in the case of New South Wales-is that, instead of the measures taken at the Premiers Conference and Loan Council meeting last May actually producing a significant fall in the State component of the total public sector borrowing requirement, while we cannot precisely calculate that element as yet, all the indications are that, when it has been calculated by the Commonwealth Statistician in the next few months, we will find that almost no contribution at all has been made to reducing the State component of the total public sector borrowing requirement. Hence, once again we shall be left, in 1987-88, with a still very large total drain on national finances coming from the total government sector-the government sector overall including both the Commonwealth and the States. Of course, that is the chief element underlying, in turn, the `need' for the Australian economy to draw upon the savings of foreigners, a process which, I suppose, is more technically known as the current account deficit on the balance of payments. That is the factor which, in turn, has led over the years, particularly over the past four years, to this very large rise in the total indebtedness of Australians to foreigners.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is all private sector debt.

—Senator Maguire is interrupting to suggest that because this debt is in the name of private sector entities it has nothing to do with his Government. If Senator Maguire has some little time, I am prepared to pursue this matter, as indeed others on this side of the Senate have done. Earlier this afternoon Senator Michael Baume gave one of the honourable senator's colleagues a lesson on the same point. Senator Maguire does not appear to realise that a balance of payments deficit must be financed. There are only two ways of financing it: either by borrowing or by selling off bits of Australia-and the present Government has been doing both, I might say, at a pretty handsome clip. But as to the borrowing component, if the funds are not borrowed by governments abroad, they will have to be borrowed by private citizens abroad. It is a simple matter of arithmetic, Senator Maguire.
