I was making the point in that connection that the Government's own contribution to rectifying the overall fiscal imbalance in this country has been relatively limited, but that it has in fact, and increasingly this particular year, 1987-88, sought to place a very considerable burden in that regard upon the States. At that time I took the opportunity of connecting those observations with those made earlier this afternoon in the context of the urgency motion, calling upon the Government to address its responsibilities to the Australian people at this time, particularly in the light of the events of the last week which have been, I understand, added to today by a further 100 point fall in the Australian stock market, with a view in particular to calling upon the Government to bring down a mini-Budget before the Parliament rises for Christmas. I shall leave that particular aspect of my remarks there.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to move now to a rather different aspect of State government finances, of which of course the revenue funds provided for under the States Grants (General Revenue) Amendment Bill, constitute a most important element. In doing so I want to refer to some particularly ill-chosen remarks made in the House of Representatives when this Bill was being debated there on 20 October last, by the honourable member for Lilley, Mrs Darling. Mrs Darling, who represents a Queensland electorate, spoke in a manner which I think might have led one to wonder whether she did. Let me take a sample or two from her remarks. I am referring to page 1150 of the Hansard of 20 October. She said:

In past years the Queensland Government has reneged on its responsibilities to Queenslanders by grossly underspending in the area of public housing and missing out on the Federal dollar that it could have had to relieve that situation.
At a later point she said:

Queensland has done very well on Federal funding. In 1987-88 the Federal Government has increased public housing funding to the States and the Northern Territory to $700m . . . Queensland's allocation is as follows . . .
Then she went on to give some, in themselves, meaningless figures as to what Queensland's allocations had been under various elements of the housing program. She concluded by saying:

This makes a total of $108,781,000 of Federal funding for Queensland alone. An additional $414m has also been made available in 1987-88 for public housing under Loan Council nominating arrangements at the highly concessional interest rate of 4.5 per cent repayable over 53 years.

The facts are, of course-I would not normally speak on a matter of this kind-that the implications of the remarks of the honourable member for Lilley are totally incorrect. The truth is that in recent years, under the tender ministrations of the present Government in Canberra, the Queensland Government has been considerably disadvantaged in a number of these areas. I make it very plain, as I did earlier in my remarks before dinner, that I believe that at the May Premiers Conference and Loan Council meeting this year, there was a case for cutting back the funds available to the States, and indeed as Senator Collins is in the chamber I might add the Northern Territory, even more than was done, but only on condition that that was done in the context of an equivalent degree of financial sacrifice on the part of the Commonwealth Government also as part of, if you like, a general facing up, by Commonwealth and State governments at their respective levels of responsibility, to the real dangers confronting the nation, the evidence of which we have begun to see in a particularly crucial form in the last week or 10 days. I put that caveat to make it plain to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, and to honourable senators opposite in particular, that I am not here tonight, or at any other time, to make a special plea for special treatment for Queensland. As a matter of fact I do not believe that the Queensland Government or the Queensland people have ever asked to be given special treatment. They do ask to be given fair treatment, to be given a fair deal, to be treated equally with other parts of the Commonwealth of Australia, on all fours with the other States-with New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia-all of which States at present are enjoying, if that is the appropriate term, Labor Party governments.

But what do we actually find? We actually find that in fact Queensland, and I have very little doubt that the same applies to Tasmania and for similar reasons, is disadvantaged in a number of these areas, including those to which the honourable member for Lilley in the House of Representatives was actually referring, in particular to housing and, in addition, areas such as roads, tertiary education and Aboriginal capital grants. For example, this year Queensland will receive only $29 per capita for housing assistance. That compares with the average for the other States of $37. These comparisons are admittedly based on 1981 census data, and it may be that the 1986 census data would change them somewhat, because I understand that there has been some remarkable growth in the population of Australians of Aboriginal descent between 1981 and 1986, for reasons which are not altogether clear. Nevertheless, based on 1981 census data, some 34 per cent of the total Aboriginal and Islander population in Australia resides in Queensland. Yet that State will receive this year only 27 per cent of total Commonwealth grants for Aboriginal housing. If that were to be placed upon the same basis as that of other States, Queensland would have received almost $5m more this year under that scheme alone. Similar comparisons can be drawn in other areas. Again I emphasise that Queensland has not at any time, so far as I am aware, sought special treatment. But I think the degree of victimisation that is going on is becoming so palpable that even this Government will shortly be unable to deny it. That will certainly be stretching credulity, because the things this Government can deny are extraordinary, if I may say so to Senator Tate.

Finally, on this aspect of the performance of the State of Queensland, and having in mind, as I say, these ill-chosen remarks of the honourable member for Lilley, let me revert also to something that I referred to before dinner, when I was speaking about the recent survey by the States' Policy Unit of the Institute of Public Affairs in Perth. In those remarks I referred to what Mr McCarrey, the Director of that Institute, called the `lemon' award among State Budgets this year. That award was, as I said, then given to New South Wales, which not only expanded its total spending faster than that of any other States but in particular expanded its recurrent expenditure, as distinct from its capital expenditure, at an even faster clip proportionately than any other State. I will deal with something which I did not refer to at that time because, although I did not wish to speak about Queensland as such, the remarks of the honourable member for Lilley have led me to do so. I therefore take the opportunity to place on record in this place tonight the following fact:
Queensland has won the IPA award for the most restrained and responsible budget for the second year in succession.
These are not my words; these are the words of Mr McCarrey of the States' Policy Unit of the Institute of Public Affairs in Perth. I am quoting from its Press release. Mr McCarrey went on to say:
The award of the lemon goes to New South Wales, which budgeted for the highest increase in recurrent expenditure of all governments this year.

I think it is high time that some of the increasingly overt discriminatory financial practices against the State of Queensland were brought more closely under the financial microscope. Perhaps it is time that that process got more strongly under way. I assure Government Ministers and honourable senators opposite that that process will be got under way. To the extent that this Government feels, in its usual underhand way, that it can in fact discriminate against the people of Queensland by various slightly sly means through its centralised financial control, I think it will be the duty of senators and members from Queensland, such as myself, to begin to drag some of these nasty facts out into the light of day. I can assure honourable senators that we will have not the slightest compunction in doing so, notwithstanding the pained looks upon the faces of some honourable senators opposite at our contemplating to do so.

Those few things having been said, I simply conclude by referring again to my remarks before dinner: we have in this Bill the embodiment of the decisions taken by the Commonwealth Government and imposed upon the States at the May Premiers Conference. While, as I say, I have no quarrel with the restraint sought to be imposed upon the States at that time, what is most conspicuous about this measure is that this restraint has in no way been matched by any comparable degree of restraint-indeed, there is no restraint at all-on the part of the Commonwealth Government itself in respect of its own current programs, which, as I have pointed out and which is indeed confirmed also in this statement by the States' Policy Unit of the Institute of Public Affairs, are estimated to grow very slightly in real terms in financial year 1987-88.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Senate that these Bills which we are debating cognately tonight-the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Amendment Bill 1987 and the States Grants (General Revenue) Amendment Bill 1987-deliver the $1 billion reduction in Commonwealth grants to the States which was outlined by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in the May economic statement. General purpose capital grants to the States are to be reduced by $715m in this year, leading to an estimated fall in funds for States to spend on capital purposes of 56.5 per cent this year compared with last year.

SPEECH.PARA: The other $285m which makes up the $1 billion saving announced in the May economic statement is gained by abandoning the Federal Government's commitment to increase by 2 per cent in real terms the general revenue grants to the States in 1987-88. Instead, the Commonwealth has reduced general revenue grants to the States to just maintain their value in real terms in 1986-87. In more ways than one the Hawke Government seeks to be emulating the governments in the United States of America and Australia which responded to the first signs of the 1930s Depression by cutting government expenditure, cutting wages, reducing government borrowing and then waiting for the private sector to take up the slack by creating production and employment. Those policies that failed after 1929 again represent the economic wisdom of our times. J. K. Galbraith, commenting on the contribution of economists to the Depression of the 1930s, said:

It seems certain that the economists and those who offered economic counsel in the late '20s and early '30s were almost uniquely perverse. In the months and years following the stock market crash, the burden of reputable economic advice was invariably on the side of measures that would make things worse. In November 1929, Hoover announced a cut in taxes; in the great no-business conferences that followed he asked business firms to keep up their capital investment and to maintain wages. Both of these measures were on the side of increasing spendable income, though unfortunately they were largely without effect.
Still, the effort was in the right direction. Thereafter policy was almost entirely on the side of making things worse. Both the Democrat and Republican Parties agreed to aim for a balanced budget.

Of course, we now have the Hawke Government bringing in a balanced Budget-balanced, I remind the Senate, at the expense of low income families and individuals. The Liberals and Nationals, of course, would have cut more. We have to consider which Australians suffer as a result of these expenditure cuts. We will look at that in some detail because it becomes clear when we look at the effect that these Bills will have on the money available to the States for the funding of housing. In 1986-87 the Commonwealth made $584.7m available to the States to spend on public housing. This year it is expected to provide $385.6m. This reduction of grants available to public housing comes at a time of increasing numbers of people seeking that very public housing. The poorest Australians are being asked to wait longer for public housing while the Government has encouraged property speculators to make profits and reduce their tax liability by reintroducing negative gearing for rental property.

The Opposition has attacked the Government for cutting expenditure to the States' housing programs, but it believes that the Government should have introduced bigger expenditure cuts in this Budget and past Budgets. And, of course, the amendment which the Opposition is proposing to move also criticises the Government for not having reintroduced the negative gearing earlier. Today we hear that the Burke Labor Government has contributed State revenue to bailing out Laurie Connell and his merchant bank, Rothwells Ltd. In effect, the Western Australian Labor Government is providing financial assistance to a man who recently spent $8m acquiring seven waterfront properties on the Swan River to demolish so that he could build a $30m home.

It seems, regrettably, that modern Labor governments specialise in reducing housing for the poor while assisting wealthy property speculators. After all, in this year's Budget, Mr Keating announced the return of negative gearing for rental properties-in spite of the fact that in the White Paper on tax reform which preceded the National Taxation Summit, in arguing the justice and equity case for the abolition of negative gearing, it was shown that in 1982-83 14 per cent of individuals with negatively geared property would have had taxable incomes of over $100,000 if negative gearing had been disallowed; while less than 2 per cent would have had taxable incomes below the then average wage. The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), some honourable senators might remember, just a couple of weeks ago in an answer to a question I asked him on this matter, admitted that he could not guarantee that this incentive-a little taking up of incentivation on the other side of the House-for the landlord would guarantee the availability of cheap housing for private rental. On 16 October the State government housing Ministers expressed the same scepticism that I expressed here on behalf of the Australian Democrats about whether the restoration of negative gearing was helping to ease the rental crisis in capital cities. They called for more Federal funding for public housing programs. Hence at the time Davidson wrote:

To attempt to subsidise rental housing through easing the restriction on negative gearing by subsidising a rich renter class who may or may not pass on that benefit depending on the state of the rental market, will at best subsidise luxury accommodation, the commercial rents as well as the target group, and reintroduce a tax shelter which was blocked for very good reasons in the tax reforms of 1985.

Instead of spending the money the Government saved through disallowing negative gearing at the time for rental property on public housing, it has reduced Federal funding for public housing and reintroduced negative gearing for rental properties. To make matters worse, the Government's trade-off for this whole exercise in its backdown on negative gearing is to reduce the 4 per cent depreciation allowance for new residential construction to 2.5 per cent. The 4 per cent depreciation allowance underpins recent developments in Victoria and New South Wales at State level of rental housing trusts intended to boost construction specifically of low cost accommodation. Dropping the allowance places those trusts in jeopardy.

The question is just who is entitled to assistance from the Government in these difficult times-the owner of Rothwells bank, the property speculator looking for a tax break or perhaps those low income households and individuals who cannot afford to buy their own homes and cannot get public housing accommodation because there simply is not enough of it? The answer to this question becomes abundantly clear-or it ought to-when we look at some of the facts. The redistribution of aid to the wealthy, of which we had a very clear example today, comes at a time when the number of Australians living in poverty has increased from an estimated 780,000 in 1983 to at least 2.2 million in 1985-86, when the number of millionaires has increased from 30,000 to 50,000 in just the past year and the wealth of two Australians is reputed to have increased in one year by $2 billion, an amount far more than what is needed to lift all Australians out of poverty.

Long term unemployment has plateaued and continues to be a fact of life for at least 600,000 Australians. Poverty, which is clearly demonstrated by those figures, and a lack of adequate housing and reliance on the private rental sector are very closely related. Poor housing and social planning exacerbate the problems of people who are in stress; it contributes to ill health in that the impoverished circumstances of many families are a result of the overcrowding and social isolation which is often a response to the housing problems in which they find themselves. Poor physical environments contribute to the ill health of the community which flows from stress, anxiety, depression, abuse and interpersonal violence. Measures which alleviate the housing related problems will, in the long term, contribute to government savings in areas such as health, social security and law and order. Unfortunately, it seems beyond the wit of government to recognise this fact.

Already we have seen that recent Government changes to the private rental sector will do nothing to meet the needs of low income Australians. Yet a recent study, which was published in a supplement to the magazine Australian Society, shows that people forced into the private rental sector-the sector which is said, without any evidence whatsoever, to have been given a boost by the reintroduction of negative gearing-because there is not sufficient public housing continue to experience the highest incidence of housing-related poverty, with 20 per cent of them living below the poverty line. I point out in particular that within that 20 per cent an alarming 62 per cent of single parents who are in private rental are living below the poverty line. They have been pushed there specifically by housing costs in the private rental sector because they cannot find public accommodation. Similarly, while the incidence of after-housing poverty is not high in general terms amongst the elderly, it is prevalent amongst those elderly who live in private rental accommodation.

The same study published in Australian Society found that 30 per cent of single parents, that is, 5 per cent of all households which are in receipt of government benefits, were paying more than 50 per cent of their income on housing where they were forced into the private rental system. An estimated 40,000 Australians are homeless-they are unable to find homes either in the public or private sector-and 150,000 Australians live permanently in caravan parks. I think we should take a moment to reflect on the fact that the most poorly housed group in Australia is the Aboriginal people. The Aboriginal Development Commission estimates an unmet demand for an additional 16,000 dwellings for Aborigines, a huge amount when one considers that the estimated population of Aboriginals is 160,000. Like so many of the policies in Aboriginal affairs, successive governments' failures to provide adequate and appropriate housing is to our great shame as a nation and will, quite rightly, be receiving warranted public scrutiny in a few months when we commemorate 200 years of white occupation in Australia. Of course, many low income tenants would prefer public housing if it were available to them. In many cases, as I have demonstrated, this would make the difference between their living in poverty or managing to get above the poverty line.

The waiting lists for public housing in Australia are said, according to Julian Disney the President of the Australian Council of Social Service (ACOSS), to have doubled over the last five years. The waiting period often exceeds two years and the waiting list nationally is expected to be 250,000 households by 1990. This is the sort of situation which was greeted with such political hysteria in relation to public hospital waiting lists for elective surgery. Yet, instead of taking positive action to address the waiting list problem, as government finally did in relation to hospital waiting lists by providing more funds for public hospitals, the legislation which we are debating tonight constitutes a reduction in Federal support for public housing. As yet, we do not seem to be concerned about that set of waiting lists.

The amendment in this legislation which will allow States to nominate a larger proportion of their borrowings under the Loan Council programs for public housing than they have in the past is really very cold comfort indeed. Even if the States nominate 100 per cent of their loans component to housing-and we certainly cannot presume that they will-this amounts to a reduction of $164.4m in available capital funding, according to the figures which have been provided by ACOSS in its Budget response. In 1987-88 the loan component has been reduced by 51.8 per cent to $414m. Similarly, this year funding for the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement effectively in real terms fell by 6 per cent. To maintain the agreement funding in real terms of $740m was required. Instead, the Commonwealth will provide only $700m to the States and the Northern Territory.

The bleak picture for those people on the long public housing waiting lists is reinforced by figures on housing commencements. The predicted level of up to 130,000 in 1987-88 is a substantial increase on 1986-87 commencements and is good news for the building industry and for those in the ranks of home buyers. However, not unnaturally, the number of public housing commencements is down. The provision of adequate housing for low income Australians is, the Australian Democrats believe, one of the major challenges affecting us today, particularly if we are, as the Government has said it is, interested in helping people to get out of poverty, especially those children who are living in poverty and are members of those households which are finding themselves forced into poverty by insufficient public housing. Once they get into the private rental area, they are forced below the poverty line. This is one of the areas, however, in which the Government's contradictory expenditure policy, combined with its continuing tax concessions to the better off, produces unjust and irrational economic outcomes.

In what might seem to be a totally unrelated area, there is further evidence of this contradictory policy syndrome, if you like. At the time of the May economic statement provisions were foreshadowed for the collection of maintenance by the establishment of a child support agency, which I think would be widely supported across party lines. But it emerged in that statement that any accommodation maintenance which might be paid would be subject to a special income test. Although we have not seen legislation on this, it emerges from the papers supplied by the Department of Social Security that in the case of maintenance being paid in the form of mortgage payments and property settlements which relate to a house, the provisions proposed will mean that the family home and basic furniture will be treated as income, reducing the money available to buy food and clothing. This is an enormous anomaly. We know that the assets test which currently applies to pensions and benefits exempts the family home and allows for ownership of basic assets such as furniture and household items, but it appears that this precedent will be broken by the proposals for the new maintenance system in the case of sole supporting parents as an arrangement is being made whereby part of the maintenance will in fact maintain the family home.

It appears from what we have seen so far that the only option available will be to sell up the family home, so we will have another family out looking for accommodation-a family on a low income, a family no doubt to be pushed below the poverty line because public housing probably will not be available. There will be another family on the ever-extending waiting list. I urge the Government to look at that anomaly and perhaps to admit that, unless this form of assets test on the family home is to be introduced as a discriminatory measure against sole parents, it will have to look closely at it and change its approach before it brings before the Parliament legislation on this issue.

The Australian Democrats believe the Government's public housing policy in general needs dramatic redirection, and we need a new flexibility and openness in innovation in our search for new solutions to the problems of financing and ownership and of changing patterns of community need. It probably goes without saying that the Australian Democrats have little sympathy with the amendments which will be moved by the Opposition. Far from wanting to condemn the Government for its tardiness in reintroducing negative gearing, the Australian Democrats were appalled and remain appalled by what is yet another example of discrimination in favour of those most able to look after themselves, against the interests of the disadvantaged in this community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating cognately the States Grants (General Revenue) Amendment Bill and the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Amendment Bill. It is towards the latter of those Bills that I seek to address most of my remarks this evening; but in doing so I point out that many of the comments of a general nature that one would make about one Bill would also have direct relevance to the other. In general terms, we are talking about two Bills concerning the affairs of government in relation to spending at a time when this country is going through great traumas and uncertainty. Both of those areas of government spending, as well as every other area of government spending, need looking at urgently. I will come back to that later, but I did want to make the point that the two Bills, although different, are related to that extent.

SPEECH.PARA: The main purpose of the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Amendment Bill, as outlined in the explanatory memorandum, is to amend the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Act in accordance with the new arrangements agreed at the Australian Loan Council meeting on 25 May this year for a variety of reasons, including the payment in 1987-88 of interest free capital grants to the States of $176.1m as part of the State governments' 1987-88 Loan Council program and the payment in 1987-88 of amounts that States may nominate from their Loan Council programs and the Northern Territory from its equivalent general purpose capital advances as being for the purpose of public housing and payable under the concessional loan terms and conditions of the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. The Bill also provides for each State and the Northern Territory to provide a certified statement as to the expenditure of funds nominated for the purpose of public housing.

In 1987-88, one-third of the total amount of the State governments' Loan Council programs and the related general purpose capital assistance to the Northern Territory will be provided as a capital grant. The Bill provides, as I said, grants amounting to $176.1m this year with the remainder, an amount of $357.2m from the approved Loan Council programs for the States, representing the loan portion of the programs. The Bill also authorises the payment as advances of capital grants in the first six months of the next financial year, 1988-89, of an amount of $88.05m, pending passage of similar legislation in that year. I make the general comment that I find the Government's presentation of these figures very difficult to follow. In the second reading speech of the Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Holding) in the other place, and of course they are reflected in the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard here, the figures are complex. They are difficult to follow clearly because it would appear that there has been a major reduction in the State governments' Loan Council programs for 1987-88-a decline, in fact, of more than half, to a figure of $533.3m.

In the Senate at Question Time today the Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health, Senator Ryan, attempted to explain-I felt in an extraordinarily garbled fashion, if I might say so-that this was not the case. I hope the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) will set the record straight when he sums up the debate on this Bill this evening. I do think the presentation leaves something to be desired. What does appear quite certain, however, is that there has been a significant reduction in Federal Government funding for housing in 1987-88. Federal funding for public housing has increased by much less than the rate of inflation. That figure was announced on 30 March last. As well as that fall in real terms in funding for public housing, there has been a major reduction in general purpose grants to the States and in their Loan Council borrowings.

The exact effect of these reductions in government spending on housing is uncertain because at the Loan Council meeting on 25 May 1987 the previous arrangements were changed, and now the States can nominate up to the whole of the borrowing component of their Loan Council programs to be received as loans for public housing on the same concessional terms and conditions as those provided under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. Those loans continue to be subject, though, to the condition that the States and Northern Territory will be able first of all to meet the matching requirements of the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. As well, the States and the Northern Territory have until 31 December this year to nominate the proportion of their borrowing entitlement that they wish to go into public housing. Until then we do not know the actual amount that will go into public housing.

I should make it clear early in my remarks that the Opposition does not oppose the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Amendment Bill. However, the Opposition condemns the Government for the great damage that it has done to the housing industry and the hurt that it has caused hundreds of thousands of Australians, particularly low income earners and young married couples endeavouring to buy and/or, in the present interest rate climate, retain their first home as a result of its general economic policies and its specific policies towards the housing sector. For that reason, on behalf of the Opposition, I have circulated an amendment to the motion that the Bill be read a second time. The amendment adds the following words to the end of that motion:
``, but the Senate condemns the Government for the delay in the re-institution of negative gearing and for the pursuit of economic policies which have:
(a) forced a record number of over 161,000 Australians on to public housing lists;
(b) resulted in a long period of record high interest rates; and
(c) resulted last year in the lowest number of housing starts for the last 20 years, excepting the drought year of 1982-83''.

I elaborate on the sentiments contained in that amendment. The housing industry is vital in both economic and social terms, and Senator Powell in her remarks on behalf of the Australian Democrats concentrated on the social terms. Figures provided by the Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry-that is, the official body that looks at the housing industry and forecasts its movements-show that in real terms, at 1979-80 prices, annual private sector gross fixed capital expenditure on dwellings is between $6 billion and $7 billion each year. That is a very large figure indeed which incorporates a high level of resource usage in terms of employment, in the use of savings in the community and in borrowings from the financial system. The economic aspects of the industry are very important.

The social aspects, though, are just as important. One of the great Australian traditions has been the dream of owning one's own home. Some might say that we have placed too much store on home ownership, to the detriment of investment in other areas which may have assisted a higher economic growth rate. But that is another matter. The fact is that it always has been the goal of most Australians to own their own home. The level of home ownership in Australia is among the highest in the world, even though it has been dropping in recent years. The housing industry is highly susceptible to the overall level of economic activity and to the macroeconomic policies of government. These have an enormous effect on the availability of funds for housing, on the level of interest rates, on the inflation level and on the confidence of home buyers and investors in housing. On each count the Government stands, in the Opposition's view, condemned by the facts.

Let us look at a few of those facts. Housing interest rates have been at record levels during most of the term of the Hawke Government's 4 1/2 years in office. Despite the recent easing in some home loan interest rates, they are still far too high, and look certain to go up again in the near future. The increase in building costs in Australia in recent years has gone up broadly in line with the increases in inflation generally-probably, at a higher rate. But even at the general rate of increase, we all know that in Australia those increases have been at rates up to five times and more higher than in other Western nations. The sheer availability of finance for housing has fluctuated considerably. It has been much less available than it would have been had the Government been a less profligate spender of other people's money. During the 4 1/2 years that the Hawke Government has been in office it has managed to spend $25 billion more than it has raised in taxes. That has happened despite the fact that it has raised the overall burden of taxation to the highest level in our history. So despite massive hikes in our tax bill, the Government still needed to be a very heavy borrower on financial markets here and abroad. The Government's domestic borrowings have diverted funds away from housing and have reduced the availability of housing finance and increased its cost-that is, housing interest rates.

A recent study by the Real Estate Institute of Australia on home loan affordability has shown that mortgage payments in Australia are taking more and more of the average income earner's wage. Home owners on average are paying now up to 17 per cent more of their income on mortgage repayments than they did just a decade ago. It varies from one city to another, but in Sydney, for example, home owners are now paying 45 per cent of average weekly earnings on an average home loan. Ten years ago that figure was 28 per cent. In Melbourne the average wage earner now pays 14 per cent more of his income in home mortgage repayments than he did 10 years ago. In Brisbane the increase over that period has been 9 per cent, in Canberra 10 per cent, in Perth 3 per cent and in Adelaide 15 per cent. So the affordability of housing has diminished dramatically in the availability of funds and their costs.

The borrowings from both sources, domestic and overseas, have pushed up the Government's overall interest bill to staggering heights. This year the Government's interest bill alone exceeds $8 billion, which is more than the Federal Government spends on education and on health, and indeed it is even more than it spends on the defence of this nation. It is no wonder that the level of activity in the housing industry in the year to June 1987 fell so dramatically. Dwelling commencements in 1986-87 totalled 116,200-the smallest number for 20 years with the exception, as I mentioned earlier, of 1982-83 when Australia was in the middle of its worst drought in living memory, which had enormous impact on all economic activity. All areas of dwelling activity fell last year. I refer to private houses for owner occupation, private dwelling construction for investment and rental purposes and public housing, where public housing commencements fell for the fourth successive year.

The fall in public housing commencements is a blot on the Australian scene of which this Government should be ashamed. The number of families now on public housing lists totals 161,000. When that figure is multiplied by their dependants, the actual number of Australians who are on public housing lists is staggeringly high. It would certainly well exceed half a million people. Those 161,000 families on the waiting lists is an increase of more than 50,000 since this Government came to office-something like a 50 per cent increase. While those waiting lists grow inexorably and tragically, the Government has failed to take not only specific action but also the necessary broad economic policy decisions to improve the situation. We all know that the housing industry relies essentially on stability and consistency in the policies adopted towards it by government. The biggest investment that most individual Australians make in their lifetime is a house for their now occupation and use. They need stability and confidence to be able to undertake that and to afford the repayments which they program so many years ahead. For those concerned with investment in housing for investment/rental purposes, it is also essential that there be stability and consistency in the policy approach.

Let us look at some of the policies in recent years as far as they have affected investment in housing and other residential construction. One important area has been the depreciation allowance for residential and non-residential construction. That was an exciting measure brought in by the Fraser Government in 1981 or 1982 when it gave a depreciation allowance of 2 1/2 per cent of the value of the construction. A couple of years ago the Hawke Government put that figure up to 4 per cent. But now in this Budget it has brought it back to 2 1/2 per cent. Whether the figure should be 4 per cent or 2 1/2 per cent is a matter for debate, I guess. But what is not a matter for debate is the fact that it is unsettling in the extreme for the industry to be subject to changes of that nature-unheralded, without prior notice and without any logical reason for them.

The introduction of capital gains tax was a major impediment on investment in dwelling construction for investment and rental purposes. Of course, capital gains tax now applies to homes other than the family home in which one resides. At the same time as that tax was brought in-and these announcements were only two months apart-came the Government's announcement a couple of years ago of the abolition of negative gearing. Taken together, the capital gains tax and the abolition of negative gearing had a quite devastating effect on the housing industry. The Opposition warned the Government of the effects. The Government ignored those warnings. Now, in the latest Budget, it has restored negative gearing because it says that it is in a position to permit the restoration as a result of the introduction of the capital gains tax. But that is an absolute nonsense argument-a totally misleading and wrong argument-because when the Government introduced both measures almost simultaneously it knew that they were both coming in and therefore it should have foreseen the results of that. Quite clearly, the Government made a monstrous mistake with the abolition of negative gearing and it should have the courage to admit that now.

The prospects for the housing industry over the year ahead are, in my view, very clouded. The best indication that we have as to the Government's thinking-or, at least, the thinking of the official sources-comes in the August report of the Indicative Planning Council (IPC). That Council has forecast that in 1987-88 the total dwelling commencements will go up to 128,000 from the figure of a little over 116,000 in 1986-87. That figure needs to be looked at very carefully because it was based on a set of assumptions that are no longer valid. It was made at a time when the economic climate was vastly different from what it is now, given the events of recent days. In any case, that figure of 128,000 measures against a required demand for housing-again as stated by the IPC-of between 160,000 and 170,000. If we take the mid point of those figures, even if the 128,000 commencements for this year were maintained, there would still be a shortfall in the IPC's own estimation of a figure not far short of 40,000 dwellings. That is an enormous shortfall at a time such as now.

The climate for the housing industry has deteriorated. I have no doubt that it has deteriorated as a result of the events on stock markets and financial markets over the last couple of weeks, and the likelihood of that 128,000 being an overestimate for 1987-88, rather than an underestimate, must be very considerable indeed. Prospects for the shortfall being much greater even than the already large figure of 37,000 that was being forecast have gone up enormously.

I want to draw again to the attention of the Senate some of the terms of the Opposition's urgency motion that was passed by the Senate earlier today. That motion contained much that is relevant to the debate in which we are now engaged in respect of both the States Grants (General Revenue) Amendment Bill and the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Amendment Bill. The motion that was passed by the Senate today said, amongst other things:
That the Senate
(1) Express its concern:

(a) that Australia's gross foreign debt, at around 40 per cent of Gross Domestic Product (GDP) is now among the highest in the world, and compares with a figure of 13 per cent in the case of the United States of America;
The Senate also expressed its concern:
(b) that Australia's current account deficit in the balance of payments, which is the source of this growing debt-
the source of the debt and not the other way around-
was forecast in the Budget Papers at $11.5 billion or 4 per cent of GDP in 1987-88 compared with a figure of 3.3 per cent in the case of the United States of America;
The Senate then noted:

the state of these fundamental indicators of economic ill-health renders the Australian economy excessively vulnerable to any adverse change in world economic conditions, particularly insofar as any such change may have adverse consequences for the prices of our major export commodities;
The Senate also noted:

the serious risks for Australia which are involved in the foregoing and calls upon the Government to undertake urgently measures to speed up the pace of the economic adjustment which, as conceded in the Budget papers, has to be made.
Finally, the Senate today called upon the Government:

as an urgent first step in that speeding-up of the adjustment process, to introduce a mini-Budget directed at significantly cutting Government expenditure and reducing the total Public Sector Borrowing Requirement (PSBR) before the Parliament rises in December.

The Government voted against that urgency motion. I am pleased to note that the Opposition's motion was supported by the Australian Democrats. Having listened to Senator Powell, I can only regret that once again the Democrats are going to demonstrate their policy inconsistency approach by refusing to support the amendment I am going to move in regard to the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Amendment Bill. What my amendment is all about is very much in line with the decisions the Senate took in its urgency motion today.

The figures which are the subject of the legislation tonight were determined several months ago at the Loan Council meeting in May. Since then, and since the Budget of 15 September-indeed, since only 10 days ago-the economic world in which we live has changed dramatically. In the last week the stock market in Australia has fallen in value by about 33 per cent, the largest fall of any of the significant stock markets in the world. No one should seriously question the need for us to urgently rework our figures as individuals, as companies and, very importantly, as governments-and, therefore, our policies.

The world has changed very considerably indeed. The question now is whether the change in the financial environment in which we operate is a change that will flow through to real economic activity. That is the test for Australia over the period ahead; it is the test for the world over the period ahead. The one thing we can be absolutely certain of is that the prospects for affecting the real economies of Australia and other nations is increasing almost hour by hour. The housing industry and the other areas of government activity will in no way be sacrosanct or shielded from those processes. In the context of this legislation, I renew the Opposition's plea to the Government to look at the urgent need for a mini-Budget and for other necessary economic adjustment policy measures to be taken in this parliamentary session. In making that plea, I commend again the amendment to the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Amendment Bill which I have circulated. I move:
At the end of the motion, add:
`, but the Senate condemns the Government for the delay in the re-institution of negative gearing and for the pursuit of economic policies which have:
(a) forced a record number of over 161,000 Australians on to public housing lists;
(b) resulted in a long period of record high interest rates; and
(c) resulted last year in the lowest number of housing starts for the last 20 years, excepting the drought year of 1982-83'.

SPEECH.PARA: The principal general revenue Act of 1985 provided for an increase of 2 per cent in real terms in the 1987-88 level of financial assistance grants and identified health grants. At the Premiers Conference, however, it was decided that the 2 per cent real growth factor was to be dropped, thereby fixing the grants at the same levels as in 1986-87-another Keating promise, another failed promise, that the Australian Labor Party (ALP) and the Federal Government have failed to keep. The previous speaker, Senator Short, mentioned that Aboriginals were discriminated against in housing. Certainly the Aboriginals in Queensland have been discriminated against in housing grants. Queensland is disadvantaged by such underfunding in the areas of tertiary education, which I have mentioned, roads, housing and Aboriginal grants. Discrimination against Queensland has been going on for some time. Let us take the case of tertiary education funding. DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN TOURIST COMMISSION BILL 1987AUSTRALIAN TOURIST COMMISSION (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 23 October, on motion by Senator Richardson:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Tourist Commission Bill 1987 and the Australian Tourist Commission (Transitional Provisions) Bill 1987 are supported by the Australian Democrats. They replace the Australian Tourist Commission Act of 1967 and provide a new legislative base for reform of the Australian Tourist Commission as recommended by the Australian Government Inquiry into Australian Tourism known as the Kennedy report which was issued in 1986. These Bills broadly concur with the Kennedy report apart from the areas of private enterprise and staff conditions which have already been discussed by Senator Puplick. We will be moving amendments to this legislation which are also in accordance with the Kennedy report. Page 63 of the Kennedy report, under the heading `Preservation of the Natural Environment', states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the greater the demand for areas such as Australia's national parks, beaches or snowfields, the less of their original attractive qualities remain. These are non-renewable resources and clearly need some forms of protection from over use and despoliation.

While large scale tourism is still in its infancy in Australia, the problems of over use of attractions will not be very prominent, although a slow, persistent attrition of quality may be occurring. When numbers increase significantly over a short or long term span, the problem becomes more acute.
Further examples of the importance of factors in the social environment are mentioned on page 62 of the Kennedy report which states:

According to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs local Aboriginals face the problem of conforming to the expectations of the tourist and are in danger of being exploited as part of the exotic setting offered by the package tour. The DAA quite rightly point out that the economic value to tourism of Aboriginal culture is dependent upon the acceptance by tourists and operators that continued down grading of Aboriginal culture will destroy its value to their industry and to Australia generally.

The amendments we will be moving at the committee stage of the debate will be in accordance with the provisions in the Kennedy report. The objectives of the Australian Tourist Commission are, firstly, to increase the number of visitors to Australia from overseas and, secondly, to maximise the benefits to Australia from overseas visitors. We see our amendments noting the possible adverse environmental and social impact of tourism and we are also in accordance with the principal objectives of the Commission. Part III of the Australian Tourist Commission Bill-it is the most substantial part-deals with the constitution of the Board of the Commission. Like Senator Puplick, I shall also be moving an amendment on that matter.

Part IV of the Bill deals with the corporate planning and accountability. There is a problem with clause 29 in part IV which was also raised by Senator Puplick. It was mentioned in the Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest when the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills stated:

Given that clause (29) provides for the Minister to give directions in `exceptional circumstances' the Committee believes that subclause (4) should be drawn to the attention of the Senate in that it might be considered to insufficiently subject the exercise of legislative power to parliamentary scrutiny.

If the Minister's discretion can override the discretion of the Parliament or the people, this is certainly unacceptable to the Australian Democrats. Part VI of the Bill deals with finance and it appears that this Bill will have no additional financial impact. Over the last several years tourism has been a major growth industry for Australia. It has generated much needed employment during periods of change and economic hardship when there have also been serious problems with our export industries. There are many employment advantages in the tourist industry. Firstly, it is an employment-intensive industry and it gives rise to a large amount of casual and part time employment. It can also provide training. I draw the Senate's attention to the Australian Tourism Industry Association 1987 annual report which, under the heading `Education/Training', states:
There is a growing concern in the industry about the ability of our educational training system to cope with the gross demands of the industry.

Surveys during the year indicated clearly that recruitment into the industry was continuing very rapidly but that available spaces in courses were inadequate to meet demand from applicants or employers.
A survey in February 1987 showed applicants greatly exceeding available spaces in all states.

Initiatives for 1987-88 clearly must centre on greater industry support for NTITC, greater concentration of the Council's resources on industry training and the development of improved management training at tertiary level.
Indeed the leader in the West Australian newspaper on Thursday, 22 October, dealt with tourism. It stated:
Western Australia risks losing its share of the lucrative Japanese tourist trade unless we listen carefully to what they want-and make sure they get it.
The article further stated:

The prediction that Australia will get one million Japanese tourists a year by 1999 represents an opportunity that we cannot afford to miss. It is up to the industry to provide the level of service and facilities needed to attract them, and to encourage some of its employees to learn the language.

As well as there being possibilities for training and teachers of the trainees in direct service industries-the hospitality industries-more opportunities should also be made available in the languages area. I also draw to the Senate's attention the fact that it is very important that we encourage tourists to come here again. It is no good giving them a one-off rip-off time, thereby not encouraging them to come back again. It is most unfortunate but often the idea is to rip off tourists while they are here and not encourage them to come back to us. I would like to read to the Senate part of a letter which expresses that very well. The letter was written as a result of the article in the West Australian. It was:
I share the concern over our ability to cater for visitors, not only from Japan, but also from all shores.
Two weeks ago, as a coach driver on a scheduled tour, I stopped overnight in Kalbarri.
The motel owners informed passengers and myself that `this is a production line. We get them in, feed them and get the Bs out'.
When two of my startled passengers queried this, the owner's exact reply was, `If you don't like it, youse can rack off'.

I hardly think that that sort of attitude will encourage overseas visitors to come back to our shores. So it is very important that, whatever legislation we bring in for the tourism industry, we make sure that the people who service that industry are well trained and do know how to cope with tourists properly.

The Bill as it stands treats international tourism as an absolutely beneficial thing, but I put it to the Senate that tourism is a very mixed blessing. I can give personal examples of the effect tourism has had on Fremantle, south of Perth. Until recently, of course, Fremantle was the home of the America's Cup. What happened in Fremantle can happen anywhere, and it is a very good example of the good side and the bad side of tourism. As honourable senators may have read recently in the papers, Fremantle actually gained an award as a result of what happened there in the lead-up to the America's Cup contest. I read again from the West Australian:
The award acknowledged the city's 16-year programme of conservation and development, which according to the citation, has made it one of the country's leading tourist destinations.

There is no doubt that the city of Fremantle was very much improved as a result of the America's Cup races being held there. A number of old buildings were renovated, and renovated most attractively and sensitively, especially some of the older hotels. The town centre was upgraded. Streets and malls were made more attractive and cycleways and walkways were put in, to the benefit of the local population. There was a lot of trade and hospitality business there and there were tourist shops. There was always a very colourful and exciting atmosphere. In fact, the whole of Perth benefited from the America's Cup. We actually had shopping on a Saturday afternoon, which was unknown before. The extended hospitality hours were welcomed by most people.

However, there was a very destructive side, and I think this is what we must bear in mind when we promote tourism simply as a go-getter industry and always beneficial in itself. In Fremantle there was a rise in rents for the people who lived there permanently. Fremantle had previously been a low rental district and lots of people had lived there for many years in a low rental situation. Small blocks of flats were upgraded, sometimes taken over totally by an overseas crew, and the rents were put up, so all round the area people simply had to move out. There was the expectation that the America's Cup races would go on for longer than they did. The finals races, unfortunately, were over rather quickly. There was the expectation of more overseas visitors than there actually were, and lots of people got their fingers burnt as a result. There was also a lot of disruption to general life in the city. So, although there was a very good side of tourism as far as Fremantle was concerned, there was also a negative side which I think we need to look at as far as all areas of the tourism industry are concerned. After all, when one wants to sell up afterwards, there are not that many takers for a second-hand berth for an America's Cup yacht.

In Perth we have quite a good understanding of the impact of tourism, especially when that tourism is brought to us by the money-making aspirations of our resident millionaires. We have the example of an enormous eyesore on the Scarborough beachfront. It is known as Observation City, and no doubt it is called Observation City because it can be observed from a great distance, both north and south, on the coastline. It stands out like the proverbial sore thumb. It is the one example of Gold Coast overdevelopment on the Western Australian coast. This is another example of the desire for tourism gone absolutely mad, and again it is of no benefit to the local residents.

Another aspect that needs to be examined sensibly and sensitively is the system of penalty rates for people working in the tourist industry and allied concerns. It is an industry where people are frequently required to work after hours, and this often means that just when more staff are needed they are simply not available because the concerns cannot afford to pay them the penalty rates. If we want to increase tourism in this country, which I am sure all of us do and which the introduction of this Bill will aid, penalty rates must be looked at carefully.

The timing of the Australian Tourist Commission Bill is very interesting because we will be debating soon the Sea Installations Bill 1987, which deals with the Four Seasons floating hotel in north Queensland. This floating hotel has just been built in Singapore and it was originally expected to arrive in Townsville in October 1987, although I believe it is now expected to arrive in north Queensland by about December. It will be moored 72 kilometres out to sea off Townsville, on the John Brewer Reef, and it will be held stable by approximately 250 tonnes of chains and concrete blocks. It is expected to cater mainly for the Japanese and north American tourist markets.

The Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority gave permission for the floating hotel to be sited within the boundaries of the marine park. It was feared that mooring the hotel over the Great Barrier Reef would destroy the very area the tourists wanted to see. The Australian Conservation Foundation movement in Queensland and other environment groups brought to the attention of the Government the fact that a hotel moored there could destroy what people were coming to see. As a result, the owners have undertaken not to pollute the water in the marine park and to take care with their rubbish disposal. But there is still the fear that the implications of mooring the hotel there cannot be totally known and there is a danger that pollution over which we can have no control will occur there.

As I have said, the Australian Democrats will be supporting the Tourist Commission Bill. We believe tourism is very valuable to Australia from an economic point of view and also from a more intangible point of view, in that when we do have overseas visitors here we can develop important links between individuals. These links may lead to unforeseen initiatives in trade and education but also they can lead to the general development of international understanding, with its positive influence on the prospects for world peace. For these reasons, we regard the tourism industry as very important and, provided that it is appropriately structured and efficiently managed, we hope that it will be encouraged as far as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Australian Tourist Commission Bill 1987 it is worth reflecting on the great and timely contribution the tourist industry has played towards investment growth and the building industry. It should always be remembered that the tourist industry is the first face of the Australian nation and of its people. It should always show the best face to our overseas visitors. It should also be noted that the very nature of this industry is that it is very much a people industry. It is a great employer and employs great skills.

SPEECH.PARA: The statistics show that 400,000 jobs, full and part time, are currently attributed directly or indirectly to tourism. The statistics also show that up to 6 per cent of gross domestic product is employed in the tourist industry, which is a credit to the industry itself. At present a one per cent increase in the number of visitors arriving on our shores will create 500 new jobs. That shows what a great employer the tourist industry is. Unfortunately job positions and the ability to train people in these fine skills which they can carry around the world are not available. Such facilities are not available in Sydney or Melbourne. In Melbourne the William Angliss College had more than 500 applicants for its diploma of hospitality and catering but could take on only 96 students. In Sydney there were positions at the Ryde College of Catering and Hotel Administration for full and part time management courses for 400 students. A total of 790 people turned up for enrolment and camped outside the college to make sure that they could enrol the next day. What a great disappointment to these young Australians-and the industry basically is composed of young Australians-that they cannot be employed and that there are not sufficient facilities and money going towards courses at technical and further education colleges in this growth industry.

The tourist industry has exploded for many different reasons over the last decade. It is predicted that by 1988 two million visitors will be coming to our shores, which is double the 1984 figure. There are many reasons for that and they were outlined in the speech of Senator Puplick on this Bill on a previous occasion. Senator Puplick mentioned the attraction to tourists in terms of security when holidaying in Australia, particularly visitors from Europe and the Middle Eastern areas. Another reason is the devaluation of the dollar, which has been stated many times in this chamber and does not need to be gone into in depth. But let us not forget that the main reason that visitors come to our shores is to see this great and unique nation. We have suddenly been discovered, and it is not before time because we are a great nation with a great deal to offer.

I unashamedly say, both as a Melbourne city councillor and as a Victorian National Party of Australia senator, that Victoria has the most to offer. The city of Melbourne is unique. It is unique for its gardens and its sporting events such as the Melbourne Cup which is coming up in the next week on the first Tuesday of November. The Melbourne Cup is one of the greatest, if not the greatest, horse racing events in the world. Melbourne is the home of the Victorian Football League grand final, and what a great final series it was this year with the contribution of the Melbourne Football Club. Melbourne has the charm of its trams and eighteenth century buildings.

Melbourne, being the first port of call in Victoria, has many great regional tourist areas also. I have had the privilege of visiting many of them. I recently came back from Swan Hill, a magnificent tourist attraction, and I was shown around by the Lord Mayor of that township on the Murray. It has magnificent tourist facilities. So great are those facilities that the film All the Rivers Run, shown last year on television, was filmed in the township of Swan Hill. At the weekend I had the privilege of travelling to Gisborne just outside Melbourne and visiting the Mount Aitkin Estate, which has some of the finest wines and ports in Australia. It is a tourist attraction. I see one Victorian Liberal Party of Australia senator present in the chamber, the newly elected Kay Patterson. I am sure that she would join me in saying that if I see any Victorian senator not drinking and supporting Victorian wines and ports, such as those from the Mount Aitkin Estate, I shall call them to account in this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is very irresponsible.

—I ask the honourable senator to keep listening to my speech because I shall have a lot to say about the Australian Labor Party and its contribution to tourism, particularly the contribution of New South Wales. This has been an adaptable, large and growing industry. It would grow even more if it were unhindered by this Government's fuel taxes, liquor taxes, sales taxes, entertainment taxes and so on. It would be one of the leading industries and one of the greatest contributors to solving the balance of payments crisis in this nation if only this Government would leave it alone and get off the industry's back.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition, I would like to concentrate on what I see as the main point of my speech. This industry is being slanted in a biased way by this Government and there is something rotten about this Ministry; there is tremendous Government interference. Shakespeare said, `Something is rotten in the state of Denmark'. I use those words to say there is something rotten in the city of Sydney. I speak both as a Melbourne city councillor and as a National Party senator for Victoria in expressing my concern and anger at the asset stripping of Victoria by this Government, particularly the asset stripping of the city of Melbourne. This asset stripping is being carried out by the right wing of the New South Wales Labor Party based in Sydney.

I draw the attention of this Parliament to the waste of funds associated with the move of the Australian Tourist Commission (ATC) from Melbourne to Sydney as the prime example. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown) took it upon himself to make this decision to move the Tourist Commission from Melbourne to Sydney before the report of the Kennedy Inquiry into Australian Tourism was properly handed down and debated. So he has already influenced the decision. One wonders what political pressure he put on the Kennedy inquiry to get it to come to the same conclusion. What a shocking conclusion it was when it cost over $3.3m to relocate the Commission, which involved taking only four people from Melbourne to Sydney. One wonders about the decision when they moved into a building owned by Sir Peter Abeles, a man Mr John Halfpenny has suggested we inquire into in connection with his relationship with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke).

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to climb into bed with Mr Halfpenny?

—No, I have no brief for Mr Halfpenny at all. Perhaps Mr Halfpenny, in wanting us to investigate the relationship of the Prime Minister and Sir Peter Abeles, would like us to investigate this particular aspect in moving the ATC into a building owned by Sir Peter Abeles. The Kennedy inquiry ignored the proper submission by the Tourist Commission that it preferred to stay in Melbourne; the inquiry preferred to take the absolutely insane evidence from the Footscray Institute of Technology which was based on the fact that there was a geographical difference between Melbourne and the Federal Ministry in Canberra. It said that it was conducive to policy formulation and setting of planning goals relative to the distance between Sydney and Canberra and that it was probably better if the ATC moved to Sydney. That is one of the most incomprehensible statements that I have heard for a very long time and does no justice to the reputation of what I believe to be a very fine institution. It merely dredges up the old Sydney-Melbourne rivalry and is based on the same reasoning as that given for the removal of this Federal Parliament from Melbourne to Canberra to begin with.
—It is in the Constitution. It had to be moved.

—Exactly. It was moved from the fine setting in the Exhibition Building in Melbourne to Canberra. That was the sort of rationale that a previous government used and the advice on which it acted in moving the Parliament to Canberra. Section 125 of the Constitution enshrines the rivalry between Melbourne and Sydney. If this Prime Minister is fair dinkum about justifying referendums in 1988, he should put section 125 to the people because it blatantly discriminates against the city of Melbourne.
—Going back 100 years is definitely raking over old coals.

—We do not forget. Section 125 says that the territory containing the seat of government of the Commonwealth shall be in an area `not less than 100 miles from Sydney'. I will not read the whole section because we all know what the point of it was. It shows just how far back this rivalry between Sydney and Melbourne goes and the New South Wales Right is continuing this rivalry at the expense of Melbourne. The plot certainly thickens, as I said before, especially when we hear that the ATC has moved to a building owned by one of Mr Hawke's good mates. Of course, Mr Halfpenny has called for an inquiry into the relationship between these two characters. However, I do not believe that Mr Halfpenny's concern is at all genuine. He has never had much concern for the Australian people. A more likely explanation is that Mr Halfpenny is still dirty on the Prime Minister for ringing him up late on election night and declaring that he had won the sixth Senate seat in Victoria. Victoria is in danger of losing the race for a major telecommunications contract because of the expected New South Wales election.

Parliamentary sources claim that a deal has been done by the NSW Right-wing faction to ensure the contract will be . . . delivered to New South Wales.
